*Thread Reply:* i'm from architecture degree but transitioned to UI/UX in Apple Academy! so far i really enjoy how both field, whether it's architecture and UI/UX, is very human-oriented. I'm grateful to learn design principles such as hierarchy, gestalt, semiotics and others through my bachelor degree so it's quite easy for me to transition. I'm currently freelancing as an architect while also doing UI/UX and having a good time in both works!

üôå Mirta
Marcus
2022-06-07 18:36:21

*Thread Reply:* Depends on how involved you are, as a designer, in the project. The more involved with the development team, they more they would probably have to know some basic Comp Sci concepts in order for their designs to be feasible with both efficiency and other factors.

I usually prototype my idea by starting with some basic paper sketches of what the app will do. From there I make a web map of the contents of the app, and then I would move on to making a basic wireframe concept of the app, defining more of the UI for the app as I'd progress.

‚ù§Ô∏è Linda D (Apple), Mike S (Apple), Tiago
C√©lia
2022-06-07 18:39:08

*Thread Reply:* Designers shouldn't have to code IMO, but it's always nice to have some knowledge for when you're designing things, so you can avoid doing things that can't really be done in code.

Also prototyping, mainly Figma nowadays. It's just so easy, and makes the timeline from ideation to prototype lightning fast ‚ö°

*Thread Reply:* Hey everyone! I'm Willey and I work as a project manager at the University of Pennsylvania designing apps to improve health equity and access for the LGBT+ community. My favorite work of design is actually a technique, which is Japanese joinery or sashimono. I love how they assemble furniture and other wooden items without nails, using both simple and highly complex wood joints!

Marcus

*Thread Reply:* I am Marcus, and I am an iOS programmer by trade who is interested in learning more about mobile design. I'd say my favorite piece of design would be the recent trend of more general flat designs (e.g., Coinbase, Twitter, etc). I'm generally a huge fan of this design trend due to how second nature concepts like grids come with these designs.

‚ù§Ô∏è Linda D (Apple), Heidi
Christopher

*Thread Reply:* üëã I‚Äôm Chris, I design and build a family of music apps (ChordBank). I have to say, my favorite piece of design I ever saw was the juxtaposition of two objects at the Cooper Hewitt museum: A spacesuit from the 1990s, next to the most intricuit inuit parka from‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm not exactly sure when but much earlier than that made out of, I think, some kind of whale intestine. Floored me to see two very different cultures solving similar problems with very different technologies.

*Thread Reply:* I'm Andrew Hall. I'm a hobbyist developer with 2 apps in the App Store: Lifeorities and StarshipSECorps. I enjoy design in digital form like apps (so many wonderful categories of apps with unique designs!) and physical designs like personal electronic devices. I love organization, hierarchical categories of information and how to display data. As a systems engineer, I like to find ways to organize design data and link the data together.

*Thread Reply:* the last ‚Äúdesigny‚Äù thing that made me smile as I worked on it were these small multiples of scale patterns. There are multiple ways to play different scales, and I needed a way to communicate which one was to users who didn‚Äôt have words to know which was which.

üëç Sahand, Linda D (Apple)

Thibaut
2022-06-07 19:49:13

*Thread Reply:* The thing I'm proud having come up with recently is more a method than a product: it's a way to select variants of a tint when working on a colour palette. Colour has always been difficult for me, still is, so this might explain the pride. It builds upon @Linda D (Apple)'s work at Lyft (thanks!), as described in this post. Tools play a great role in shaping the products we come up with, so we have to be picky about them, improve them when possible, and come up with some others if need be.

bureau.tsailly.net
Bureau ¬∑ Color variations
Bureau is a blog written by Thibaut Sailly about interface design
Original URL: https://bureau.tsailly.net/2022/03/color-variations.html

Paul S (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:15:18

*Thread Reply:* @Anca Yes, we went through each symbol and specified which parts should dim, and in what order. In fact, we internally use the same unified annotation interface that we've added to the SF Symbols app this year!

2022-06-07 20:16:29

‚ÄúPractice, practice and more practice‚Äù - Words of wisdom from Paul Sim

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 20:25:06

@Emilie asked > What design program do you prefer for creating the symbol paths...Sketch, Illustrator or something else?

Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:26:28

*Thread Reply:* For custom symbols, I prefer using Illustrator. But Sketch works well too

üíé Heidi
Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:26:38

*Thread Reply:* Illustrator‚Äôs blending tools are helpfull

Mike L (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:31:51

*Thread Reply:* For variable templates that will use interpolation, I personally like to nudge points around in a font editor before going back to Illustrator, this way I get more info on the number of points and the point order

Lance W (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:34:51

*Thread Reply:* Illustrator and Glyphs 3

üëç Mike L (Apple)
Emilie
2022-06-10 00:48:52

*Thread Reply:* @Mike L (Apple) Interesting. I‚Äôve never used a font editor, do you have a recommendation? Getting points correct for interpolation an issue I ran into with Sketch.

Mike L (Apple)
2022-06-10 03:30:08

*Thread Reply:* I‚Äôve used Glyphs3 (Glyphs App) same as Lance mentioned, but other popular font editors include RoboFont and FontLab. All have fairly good documentation (and forums) so you should be able to get up and running quickly

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 20:25:49

@Matt asked > When would we be able to see variable fonts come to the SF Font Family? It would be awesome to have this along with SF Symbols.

Paul S (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:26:24

*Thread Reply:* The SF Pro and SF Compact fonts that are installed with the SF Symbols app are variable!

üôå Cristian-Mihai, Matt
Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:27:14

*Thread Reply:* BTW, SF Symbols 4 and the updated fonts should be going live this morning.

‚ù§Ô∏è Andrew
Florian
2022-06-07 20:30:17

*Thread Reply:* They are üôÇ

Peter
2022-06-07 20:33:12

*Thread Reply:* Out of curiosity, the new SF Symbol variable colors for values from zero-to-one (like volume and signal strength symbols)... are those implemented as a variable font axis?

Paul S (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:37:06

*Thread Reply:* Variable color is not available in the fonts, unfortunately. For showing different rendering modes and variable color in design comps, we recommend using the Edit &gt; Copy Image

Peter
2022-06-07 20:39:46

*Thread Reply:* Thanks, Paul!

Andrew
2022-06-07 22:09:56

*Thread Reply:* Fonts are live!

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 20:26:56

@Cristian-Mihai asked > After creating a new custom symbol, how do we add it to our app? Is it like any other SF Symbol?

Paul S (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:27:54

*Thread Reply:* After you've made and annotated your symbol in the app, choose File > Export Symbol... and bring the resulting SVG into an Xcode asset catalog. Then, you can access it like other embedded images.

üôå Cristian-Mihai
Cristian-Mihai
2022-06-07 20:28:21

*Thread Reply:* Thank you very much!

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 20:28:18

@Kriss asked > Hi! Is there any limit of layers a symbol can have?

Paul S (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:29:32

*Thread Reply:* There's not a hard-set limit in the app.

üëç Kriss
Julio (Fonts) G (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:30:42

*Thread Reply:* There isn‚Äôt a limit for practical purposes in the template either.

üëç Kriss
Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 20:28:21

@Alexander asked > Is there a way to transfer your own custom symbols with all the settings between different Mac's or pass it to other co-designers?

Paul S (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:30:45

*Thread Reply:* The file created when you choose File > Export Symbol... can be shared with other people. It can be imported back in to the SF Symbols app and should preserve all of the annotations, too!

Alexander
2022-06-07 20:32:22

*Thread Reply:* Oh nice, so it‚Äôs basically an SVG that‚Äôs on steroids. üòÑ Or is it a different file format?

Mike L (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:34:08

*Thread Reply:* Yep, File > Export Symbol will give you an SVG. If you plan on sharing it with other designers it‚Äôs best to export the latest version (4.0) so that new features like monochrome layers + variable color are included

üëç Paul S (Apple), Alexander
Alexander
2022-06-07 20:34:54

*Thread Reply:* Awesome. Thanks a lot for! üôèüôÇ

Paul S (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:35:40

*Thread Reply:* We don't recommend editing the SVGs that come out of the File &gt; Export Symbol... option, however, they're just intended for data delivery. The recommended workflow is to use File &gt; Export Template... if you want to edit the shape of the symbol, bring that template back into the SF Symbols app, do your annotation within the app, and then use File &gt; Export Symbol... for delivery.

üëç Alexander, Mike L (Apple)

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 20:29:51

@Chen-Yu asked > Is it possible to assign colors dynamically to SF Symbols rendering in multicolor mode?

Mark E (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:30:24

*Thread Reply:* Multicolor rendering mode uses the colors assigned to the symbol by the designer. Use palette mode to use a dynamic set of colors.

Paul S (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:32:01

*Thread Reply:* There are some parts of symbols in multicolor that are still controlled by colors you specify, however. For example, folder.fill.badge.plus in multicolor will keep the badge's colors locked to green and white, but you still have control over the color of the folder.

Chen-Yu
2022-06-07 20:34:35

*Thread Reply:* Is it possible to dynamically assign multiple colors to the symbol rendering in palette mode?

Mark E (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:36:01

*Thread Reply:* Yes. SwiftUI allows multiple foreground styles, and AppKit & UIKit allow an array of colors for palette mode

Chen-Yu
2022-06-07 20:37:30

*Thread Reply:* Amazing! Thanks for answering I will do some reading on how to do it

Mark E (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:38:26

*Thread Reply:* The API for AppKit/UIKit is configurationWithPaletteColors: which takes an array of colors

üëè Chen-Yu
Mike L (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:40:07

*Thread Reply:* And in SwiftUI what you want is the .foregroundStyle modifier: https://developer.apple.com/documentation/swiftui/view/foregroundstyle(_:)

üëè Chen-Yu
Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:34:37

Hi folks, anyone have any other questions? We‚Äôd love to hear it.

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 20:35:58

@Matt asked > When creating new symbols, what criteria is followed? I‚Äôve wanted to make custom symbols before but want it to match with the rest of the rest of the SF Symbol catalog.

‚úÖ Thalia E (Apple)
Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:36:36

*Thread Reply:* Awesome, we have Thalia here to answer this.

Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:36:48

*Thread Reply:* I‚Äôm sure it might take a minute to compose her many thoughts‚Ä¶

Thalia E (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:38:19

*Thread Reply:* I would start with looking at the symbols in the context of other symbols. For example, if you are drawing a symbol about astronomy, you would want to looks at symbols that are lated like the moon, stars, etc.

Thalia E (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:38:51

*Thread Reply:* From there, I would start by defining the proportions, not too wide, not too tall, all related to the other symbols.

Thalia E (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:39:37

*Thread Reply:* And next I'll try to match the stroke thickness, roundness of the shapes, angles. It all depends on what you are trying to draw.

üëç Matt
Thalia E (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:39:58

*Thread Reply:* Let's say you need a telescope. Then I'll probably try to match some of the angles of other symbols.

Thalia E (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:40:48

*Thread Reply:* It's about looking at the context and iterating to get the best results. It's also good to look at the symbol in small and big sizes, to craft the best drawing possible for all scenarios.

Lance W (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:40:49

*Thread Reply:* Matching the line weight within SF Symbols is a good metric to follow. Also, referencing the scale and alignment of SF Symbols for shapes that are similar to what you are trying to make is a good place to start. For example, if your custom symbol is circular, scale it similar to a circle in SF Symbols.

‚ù§Ô∏è Sarah M (Apple), Lexline
üôå Stanislav, Lexline
Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 20:37:36

@Marcus asked > Are there any books you'd recommend reading regarding topics like typography, color theory, grid designs, and anything else regarding mobile UI design?

üëç Robert, Brandon, Gennadii
Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:38:12

*Thread Reply:* Grid systems: Grid system - josef m√ºller brockmann

Linda D (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:38:32

*Thread Reply:* The Elements of Typographic Style!

üôå Paul S (Apple), Sarah M (Apple), Peter, Marcus, Anders
üëç Jimmy P (Apple), Marcus
Jimmy P (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:38:57

*Thread Reply:* The 1923 ATF Catalog and Specimen book!

Thalia E (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:44:07

*Thread Reply:* Interaction of Color if one of my fav books!

üëç Linda D (Apple), Sarah M (Apple), Andrew
Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 20:39:10

@Austin asked > How would you convince a product team to adopt SF Symbols that already has a wide array of their own custom icons?

Linda D (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:39:20

*Thread Reply:* @Paul S (Apple)?

Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:41:02

*Thread Reply:* But do their symbols have variable color support?!

üòÜ Paul S (Apple), Mike L (Apple), Austin, John
Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:41:54

*Thread Reply:* A big advantage is that there are so many symbols to choose from so extending the library is easy. And also the way symbols are designed to work with text (font weight matching, small and large variants). Right to left support

üëç Austin
Paul S (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:42:23

*Thread Reply:* As I said in the talk last year, the kind of design that requires no additional work from me is the best kind of design! üòù

But really, the team has been working on SF Symbols as a way to help people make apps that look fantastic and blend seamlessly with the rest of Apple platforms. Even more importantly, SF Symbols are also designed with accessibility and inclusivity in mind. They react to things like Dynamic Type and Increased Contrast automatically, which is a big win for users of your app.

üëç Austin, Linda D (Apple), Lawrence
üëç:skin_tone_3: Mike S (Apple)
üíØ Alexander, Linda D (Apple), Sarah M (Apple)
üòç Sarah M (Apple)
Lance W (Apple)
2022-06-07 20:43:14

*Thread Reply:* Symbols offer many benefits: visual craft and integration with the system font, accessibility features including localized variants for many languages and scripts. Familiarity with users across the platforms. Smaller app footprint.

üëç Austin
üôå Sarah M (Apple)

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 22:29:51

@Kenneth asked > Not really related to the session, but are we allowed to export and use SF Symbols in a cross platform app (e.g. an app for Windows/Linux/Mac), or are the symbols only allowed for use on Apple platforms?

Scott S (Apple)
2022-06-07 22:30:43

*Thread Reply:* SF Symbols are for Apple platforms only.

Kenneth
2022-06-07 22:31:04

*Thread Reply:* Okay, thanks

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 22:30:55

@Sean asked > Hey! Thanks for the epic video! Is there anyway to use new symbols from iOS 16 in iOS 15 and below? Thanks üòÄ

üëÄ Andrew
Paul S (Apple)
2022-06-07 22:32:04

*Thread Reply:* It's possible to export a new symbol using File &gt; Export Symbol... and bring that into your app to support lower deployment targets. Remember to adjust the symbol version accordingly, though! 3.0 for last year's releases and 2.0 for the year before that.

‚ûï Mike L (Apple)
‚ù§Ô∏è Andrew, Fabian
Patrick H (Apple)
2022-06-07 22:36:36

*Thread Reply:* Note that you can still use the latest template format (4.0) with custom symbols even when deploying to earlier deployment targets as long as you are using Xcode 14 to compile your app. Naturally, the new content features won't be present on those earlier releases, so you need to be careful about which template content features you use. Safest of course is to just export with the older template versions as Paul recommends.

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 22:31:22

@Christian asked > I‚Äôd love to hear more about what it was like working on this massive update to SF Symbols. How do you go about figuring out which symbols to choose? Is there a lot of collaboration across teams within Apple for such projects? Also: amazing work!

üëÄ Mike S (Apple), Kenneth
Thalia E (Apple)
2022-06-07 22:33:31

*Thread Reply:* I think I can answer the second part of the question only üòâ but yes, there is definitely a lot of collaboration between teams to define what are the best symbols and design that fit best in the UIs. We want to make the symbols as good as possible, so there is a lot of iterations too!

Christian
2022-06-07 22:34:22

*Thread Reply:* I can‚Äôt imagine the amount of work it must take when the library is so huge and each symbol is so carefully crafted. Thanks for your answer!

üòÑ Mike S (Apple), Luca
Paul S (Apple)
2022-06-07 22:34:28

*Thread Reply:* There's also an incredible amount of work that comes in from the frameworks and platform engineering sides to support all these new features like Variable Color and different rendering modes!

üôå Mark E (Apple), Luca
üíØ Thalia E (Apple), Mike S (Apple), Travis B (Apple)
Lance W (Apple)
2022-06-07 22:34:57

*Thread Reply:* For adding new symbols: it‚Äôs a combination of supporting new platform features, adopting symbols for existing features and identifying concepts that have broad utility and application across a variety of apps and contexts.

üôå:skin_tone_3: Mike S (Apple)
Christian
2022-06-07 22:35:42

‚ù§Ô∏è Mike S (Apple), Luca, Thalia E (Apple)
ü§ó Paul S (Apple), Mike S (Apple), Paolo M (Apple)

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 22:42:09

@Elizabeth asked > I may have missed this in the SF Symbols video, but I was wondering: how do these new rendering modes interact with WidgetKit rendering using the new lock screen widget layouts like .accessoryCircular etc?

Scott S (Apple)
2022-06-07 22:44:13

*Thread Reply:* Great question. For consistency, we suggest using monochrome, hierarchical, or automatic, but WidgetKit may not actually end up enforcing that in the betas.

üëç Elizabeth, Lance W (Apple)
üëç:skin_tone_3: Mike S (Apple)
Scott S (Apple)
2022-06-07 22:44:53

*Thread Reply:* We also welcome your feedback on WidgetKit and SF Symbols in general as you get a chance to use them together. We learn from you, too!

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-07 22:45:21

@Tyson asked > Do variable colors animate automatically when changed?

Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-07 22:46:12

*Thread Reply:* Hi @Tyson can you elaborate a bit?

Paul S (Apple)
2022-06-07 22:47:51

*Thread Reply:* There isn't any animation when the variable color percentage changes and causes a layer to "dim" or "un-dim." The change appears instantly.

:thumbsup_all: Mike S (Apple), Tyson
Tyson
2022-06-07 22:48:17

*Thread Reply:* Okay, thank you.

:thumbsup_all: Mike S (Apple)
Lance W (Apple)
2022-06-07 22:48:19

*Thread Reply:* The path color will instantly change according to the corresponding percentage value.

üôå:skin_tone_3: Mike S (Apple)
üëç Tyson, Sarah M (Apple)
Patrick H (Apple)
2022-06-07 22:50:46

*Thread Reply:* Using variable colors does not automatically animate across the visual states. However it is entirely possible to add animation to Symbol just as you would to other UI Images using the UI framework animation facilities of your choice.

Tyson
2022-06-07 22:51:45

*Thread Reply:* Right, thank y‚Äôall!

Sarah M (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:02:11

We‚Äôre curious to hear about your experience as designers! What is the most difficult part of the design process to you? Why? üßµ

Sile G (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:04:01

*Thread Reply:* Presentation üòÖ

Andrew
2022-06-08 00:04:17

*Thread Reply:* I'm a solo founder with a keen interest in design. I understand layout basics & am comfortable with the mechanics of using Sketch etc. if needed. But, I struggle with developing a Design Eye for what works. Any recommendations other than just studying who won the Design Awards?

Lexline
2022-06-08 00:05:37

*Thread Reply:* Umm, all of it??? My designs just never look right üòÖ

Matt
2022-06-08 00:06:00

*Thread Reply:* Starting the design, when you‚Äôre beginning something, you have so many ideas flowing through your head, and it‚Äôs hard to choose one! I sometimes get stuck on this, so I draw each idea and choose what looks best.

Sarah M (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:08:09

*Thread Reply:* @Andrew Looking at other apps not just for inspiration but to understand patterns of what works and what is familiar, is a great way to refine your design eye. But craft also takes practice and iteration. Keep doing the work and you‚Äôll learn and improve üí™

Sile G (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:08:31

*Thread Reply:* @Matt That's a lot of work to draw every idea! Do you ask for people's feedback at early stage?

Andrew
2022-06-08 00:10:01

*Thread Reply:* Thanks @Sarah M (Apple) it's finding the other apps and having someone say what's good/bad about specifics that I struggle with.

Matt
2022-06-08 00:10:52

*Thread Reply:* Sometimes, if I like multiple ideas, I‚Äôll design them in XD or Sketch and see what might be easier to use; I usually think about how the user would interact with it instead of myself. For example, here are two versions of a design in the early stages:

^ @Sarah M (Apple)

CleanShot 2022-06-07 at 18.10.40@2x.png
Majo C (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:10:53

*Thread Reply:* @Lexline keep on the hard work! practice makes the master üí™

:thumbsup_all: Lexline, Sile G (Apple)
Lexline
2022-06-08 00:14:19

*Thread Reply:* Hehe definitely!

üßë‚Äçüíª Majo C (Apple)
Sile G (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:16:02

*Thread Reply:* @Matt My approach is same. Filtering ideas by drawing them out, see if it makes sense to myself first.

ü§© Matt
Sarah M (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:16:36

*Thread Reply:* @Andrew it can be difficult and oftentimes subjective! What makes an app good can rely on many factors. Does it solve a real need? Is it accessible to as many people as possible? Is the content relevant, useful and polished? To understand what is good and bad may also require conversations, critiques or collaboration with other designers or disciplines.

Lexline
2022-06-08 00:16:54

*Thread Reply:* @Matt Same!! I‚Äôll usually design 2 or 3 versions then ask for feedback if I can‚Äôt figure out which is better

‚ù§Ô∏è Sarah M (Apple), Sile G (Apple), Leonard, Adrien
Majo C (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:17:52

*Thread Reply:* @Matt that‚Äôs a great approach! consider also test your designs with others, it doesn‚Äôt have to be high fidelity, you‚Äôll learn so much about how others think and what do they expect from the UI üôÇ

üëç Matt
Sile G (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:18:57

*Thread Reply:* The problem is people don't always see the potential of an idea if it's not high fidelity üòú

ü§£ Majo C (Apple)
Sam
2022-06-08 00:20:36

*Thread Reply:* For UX, it‚Äôs trying to consider all perspectives and all the ways our users interact with their device. My team has been working on a medical app for cardiologists and I stress about not letting any harm into the world as a result of a design choice (how forgiving should certain actions be, how can someone reverse an accidental action, is every corner fully VoiceOver-labeled and contrast is correct in both color schemes, etc) -Sam

‚ù§Ô∏è Andrew
Sam
2022-06-08 00:22:35

*Thread Reply:* When I‚Äôm in visual design mode, the main difficulty is trying to balance uniqueness (or branding) while staying true to the platform. -Sam

üíØ Andrew
Sarah M (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:23:03

*Thread Reply:* Design decisions have the potential to really impact peoples lives. I like that you‚Äôre empathizing with the weight of those decisions!

Majo C (Apple)
2022-06-08 00:23:21

*Thread Reply:* @Sile G (Apple) True! I found useful to set the right expectations about what I want and don‚Äôt want feedback about. That way if the Visual Design is not ready, they know they should only focus on reviewing the experience.

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 18:59:34

@Linda D (Apple) added a workflow to this channel: Design - Ask a Question.

Linda D (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:01:05

Welcome to Q&A with the HIG Team! For the next hour, we‚Äôre looking forward to answering your questions about the Human Interface Guidelines, what went into the redesign, and related things! (Did you know we just redesigned it???)

Select the‚ûïicon from the lower left, and find the Ask A Question workflow. Type in your question and it will be delivered directly to the team. We‚Äôll answer as many questions as we can. While it‚Äôs unlikely we‚Äôll be able to address every question, all your submissions are valuable; thank you for taking the time! üöÄ

Let‚Äôs kick it off! ü™© And welcome HIG team! @Kathryn Y (Apple) @Doug L (Apple) @Ben S (Apple) @Mike S (Apple) @Sile G (Apple) @David L (Apple)

https://developer.apple.com/design/

Apple Developer
Design - Apple Developer
Find documentation and resources for designing great apps for Apple platforms.
Original URL: https://developer.apple.com/design/
Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 19:05:34

@Austin asked > Thank you for the new HIG! Especially appreciate that it starts from UI elements and themes and then mentions platform considerations, instead of being branched off into different platforms only. > > Are there good examples that come to mind of intentionally breaking the HIG for good reason (after knowing it well)?

Linda D (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:08:40

*Thread Reply:* Great question! I think that starts coming down to the customization you'd love to do for the app. For example there's no hard and fast rule that you have to use SF Symbols, or Apple Typefaces or a specific aesthetic for your app (and that's even more true for games).

Think of the HIG as a great "base" for what you're doing, and tailor the guidance based on what makes the most sense for your users!

üëç Austin, Izzy Z (Apple), Robert, Alberto
üëå Ryan
Linda D (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:09:56

*Thread Reply:* @Kathryn Y (Apple)‚Äôs also done a great job at wording the language of the HIG so we rarely ever say "don't" or "never" unless that's really true.

üëç Austin, Izzy Z (Apple)
‚ù§Ô∏è Dan, Marianka
Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 19:05:38

@Duncan asked > What are the key changes in the advice being given in the revised HIG, if any?

Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:06:51

*Thread Reply:* Hey Duncan, a lot of the content in the HIG carries through from previous versions. But a lot of the older content was adjusted for clarity and we removed things that no longer seemed all that relevant. It‚Äôs hard to go through all the specifics but pretty much every page needed to be edited.

Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:07:41

*Thread Reply:* We also started adding in new guidance for iOS 16, macOS Ventura, and watchOS 9 (though there‚Äôs still a lot more coming this summer

Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:08:45

*Thread Reply:* One example I recall was the Buttons page. There was content in there about placard buttons and bezel buttons but those really aren‚Äôt used these days

Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:09:20

*Thread Reply:* We also removed some of the content about full color icons in toolbars, for example, since that‚Äôs not something modern apps do all that much of.

Kathryn Y (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:10:58

*Thread Reply:* Another key change is in perspective: Rather than starting with guidance for an iOS experience, the revised HIG encourages designing the experience first and then adjusting it as needed to run great on each platform.

üëè Marianka, Robert, Justin
Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:10:59

*Thread Reply:* We added a lot of new information in the Patterns section for things like Searching or Sharing. That kind of content was spread out in component pages previously and missed a lot of important information and context when it was tied to specific controls

‚ù§Ô∏è Dan, Duncan, Justin
Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 19:11:38

@Willey asked > First off, congrats on the new HIG! I love how much more comprehensive it is. What are best practices when designing an app that is cross platform? Should the app design's adapt to the respective OS' design guidelines e.g. HIG on iOS, Material You on Android, and Fluent on Windows, or stick with one for a consistent user experience across different platforms (even though it might look slightly out of place depending on the OS)?

Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:12:52

*Thread Reply:* The best approach is to follow the relevant platform conventions. Many of them exist because of how the hardware functions. So ignoring that leads to software that feels disconnected from the hardware.

üëç Justin
Austin
2022-06-08 19:13:12

*Thread Reply:* I also wonder to what extent it's applicable to the web, especially considering seeing more web apps coming from Apple!

:thumbsup_all: Justin
Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:13:22

*Thread Reply:* Apps that are designed once for all platforms will never feel right everywhere

‚ù§Ô∏è Marianka, Willey, Chris, Justin, Kyle
‚òùÔ∏è:skin_tone_2: Heidi
‚òùÔ∏è Violet, Justin
üíõ Violet, Justin
üíØ Violet, Justin
üî• Justin
Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:14:11

*Thread Reply:* It does apply, there are differences in conventions between web and apps.

Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:14:47

*Thread Reply:* Some of the difference are pretty easy to address. Like not using ‚ÄúClick this button‚Äù in an app that only runs on touch screen devices

üëÜ Justin
Linda D (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:16:40

*Thread Reply:* ^ huge pet peeve! Also Android and iOS differ a lot in how "back" functionality works for example. So making sure that the design patterns follow system conventions helps quite a bit to not make your app feel like it's alien to the platform

üçî Austin, Justin
‚òùÔ∏è Violet, Justin
üíõ Violet, Justin
Willey
2022-06-08 19:20:01

*Thread Reply:* Thanks for the insight, @Mike S (Apple) and @Linda D (Apple)! They are really helpful. I'll definitely share them with my team who insists on having the same design across different platforms (hamburger menus and FABs everywhere!)

Linda D (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:22:50

*Thread Reply:* Look I love a good FAB but only when I've designed for Android in the past! Thanks for the question @Willey hope that helps because yes, you can be 80%-90% consistent where you can but those platform details matter

üëç Willey, Justin
Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 19:13:14

@Richard asked > I'd love to know more about the process of evolving the HIG. > > How do you identify things that feel out of date and less relevant, as well as spotting new design trends within Apple that you feel need documenting?

Doug L (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:15:00

*Thread Reply:* This is a great question. Multiple things influence this. One is our work (in evangelism) with developers. Questions that we get during this work can often spark ideas for new areas of guidance, or new details to add to pages

Doug L (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:16:24

*Thread Reply:* Another thing that influences the HIG is the work of our design and engineering teams, naturally. As the platforms evolve, there are needs to overhaul pages, or whole sections, to match the direction of the platform (or multiple platforms)

üôå Richard, Linda D (Apple)
Linda D (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:17:32

*Thread Reply:* +1 to what Doug said! We talk with so many designers throughout the year and for this particular redesign we reached out specifically to the community to get input on where we could improve the HIG.

Doug L (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:17:57

*Thread Reply:* I am resisting the urge to point out the various sections that are in need of work now, although I‚Äôd like to illustrate the point I‚Äôm making by doing so

üòÑ Richard, Leonard, Linda D (Apple), Alberto
Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 19:13:39

@Austin asked > What‚Äôs stayed the same in the HIG over the past decades?

Kathryn Y (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:15:28

*Thread Reply:* Although many details have changed, I think it's the keen focus on keeping the user experience at the center of design that's at the heart of the HIG, from the earliest days to the present.

üëç Austin
Linda D (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:38:59

*Thread Reply:* Yes the earliest HIG (I believe from 1977???) continually emphasized the human nature of computers. How computer should conform to people and not the other way around. We are still very much firm believers of this, but with more nuance on what that means ergonomically, inclusively, as a holistic experience.

‚ù§Ô∏è Jordan, Austin, Violet, Justin
üíõ Violet

Linda D (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:18:47

*Thread Reply:* That's a great question! I want to say that almost every section was rewritten to take out old, missing, or revised guidance üòÖ It was a huge haul.

Two sections that I personally love:

Linda D (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:20:48

*Thread Reply:* Inclusion: We're SO happy this page is here because it speaks not only to good design guidance but our values The new Platform pages: These are brand spanking new and give a nice overview of "getting started with designing for [ios/mac/etc]" that also speak to how many people use these devices and the considerations you need to have.

developer.apple.com
Inclusion - Foundations - Human Interface Guidelines - Design - Apple Developer
An inclusive app puts people first by prioritizing respectful communication and presenting content and functionality in ways that everyone can access and understand.
Original URL: https://developer.apple.com/design/human-interface-guidelines/foundations/inclusion
developer.apple.com
Platforms - Platforms - Human Interface Guidelines - Design - Apple Developer
Platforms
Original URL: https://developer.apple.com/design/human-interface-guidelines/platforms/overview

üëç Dan
Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 19:15:50

@Jessiah asked > Hi, nice work on the redesign, I've been going through it this morning! I have a question about color. > > On this page: https://developer.apple.com/design/human-interface-guidelines/foundations/dark-mode there's the advice "At a minimum, make sure the contrast ratio between colors is no lower than 4.5:1. For custom foreground and background colors, strive for a contrast ratio of 7:1, especially in small text." > > I aim for high contrast as much as possible, but 4.5:1 is pretty limiting, and I don't think Apple always follows this rule themselves. Specifically I'm wondering about the systemColors such as systemOrange, systemMint etc, many of which have quite low contrast against white (i.e., in Light Mode). What is the intended purpose of these colours? Is it meant for text/SF Symbols? Because if so, systemMint comes in at 2.02:1 against white. Should we ever even use systemYellow? Or can we just rely on users turning on Increase Contrast if they need to? But maybe someone doesn't want to have to increase contrast for everything just so they can see that darn yellow text. > > Any insight on the intended use of these systemColors would be greatly appreciated. Thanks!

developer.apple.com
Dark Mode - Foundations - Human Interface Guidelines - Design - Apple Developer
Dark Mode is a systemwide appearance setting that uses a dark color palette to provide a comfortable viewing experience tailored for low-light environments.
Original URL: https://developer.apple.com/design/human-interface-guidelines/foundations/dark-mode
üôå Robert, Linda D (Apple), Alison
üëç Adi, Linda D (Apple), Anqi
Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:16:19

*Thread Reply:* Awesome questions Jessiah! I could take the next 45 minutes trying to answer. üôÇ

üòÑ Jessiah, Linda D (Apple)
Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:16:50

*Thread Reply:* In short, the rules about color contrast are a bit tricky, it‚Äôs not black and white (forgive the pun)

üëé Robert, Linda D (Apple)
üòõ Jessiah, Linda D (Apple), Justin
üëç Jessiah, Linda D (Apple)
Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:17:42

*Thread Reply:* Higher contrast is always better but there are mitigating circumstances that make it OK to have lower contrast. For example, text size. The larger or bolder the font, the easier it is to read given the same color value

üëÜ Justin
Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:18:16

*Thread Reply:* But a color choice that works for large type can be too low contrast for smaller text.

Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:18:59

*Thread Reply:* The same applies for icons or glyphs (symbols): Finer features are harder to naturally harder to discern so boosting contrast is useful

Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:19:45

*Thread Reply:* As for system colors, they don‚Äôt all work equally well in every circumstance. Orange or mint on a light background probably isn‚Äôt the best choice. Definitely not as legible as blue or purple

Robert
2022-06-08 19:23:57

*Thread Reply:* None

Screen Shot 2022-06-08 at 11.23.36 AM.png
Jessiah
2022-06-08 19:24:49

*Thread Reply:* Yeah I was wondering about the Notes app, it looks like some darkening is being applied to the tint colour in this case, rather than using the default system color?

Jessiah
2022-06-08 19:24:57

*Thread Reply:* to

Marianka
2022-06-08 19:28:34

*Thread Reply:* I‚Äôve worked on products where I had to incorporate colours that are notoriously difficult to have high contrast - like teal/green.

In those instances i‚Äôve provided darker versions, that are perhaps not so aesthetically pleasing, but pass AA/AAA to assist visually impaired users once they enable accessible system settings. It has worked for me ‚ù§Ô∏è

üëç Jessiah, Justin
Jessiah
2022-06-08 19:29:40

*Thread Reply:* Yeah for our app which uses orange tint, we‚Äôve used our own custom orange for light mode, and only use the sytemOrange for dark mode

‚ù§Ô∏è Robert, Justin
Heidi
2022-06-08 19:30:21

*Thread Reply:* My personal guide when designing is to make all elements that need to be legible and clear have strong contrast. Details like a divider, for example, can be lighter to convey less prominence. But text should always be readable and accessible.

üëç Justin
Linda D (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:35:22

*Thread Reply:* I also feel like I could spend the next hour speaking about this üòÖ so GREAT question. As you might know, the 4.5:1 contrast ratio comes from WCAG 2.0 guidelines. While WCAG 3.0 is still not officially "out" they have an improved way of calculating contrast that I find incredibly interesting: https://www.w3.org/TR/wcag-3.0/#visual-contrast-of-text

w3.org
W3C Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) 3.0
The W3C Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) 3.0 provide a wide range of recommendations for making web content more accessible to users with disabilities. Following these guidelines will address many of the needs of users with blindness, low vision and other vision impairments; deafness and hearing loss; limited movement and dexterity; speech disabilities; sensory disorders; cognitive and learning disabilities; and combinations of these. These guidelines address accessibility of web content on desktops, laptops, tablets, mobile devices, wearable devices, and other web of things devices. They address various types of web content including static content, interactive content, visual and auditory media, and virtual and augmented reality. The guidelines also address related web tools such as user agents (browsers and assistive technologies), content management systems, authoring tools, and testing tools.
Original URL: https://www.w3.org/TR/wcag-3.0/#visual-contrast-of-text
üëÄ Jessiah, Justin
üôå Marianka
Jessiah
2022-06-08 19:41:50

*Thread Reply:* nice I‚Äôll take a look üëç

Jessiah
2022-06-08 19:56:05

*Thread Reply:* I‚Äôm imagining a future accessibility feature that allows you to increase contrast per colour üòõ üòâ

üíõ Violet, Paulius
Jessiah
2022-06-08 19:56:29

*Thread Reply:* or colour range

üíõ Violet

2022-06-08 20:31:49

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 19:20:19

@Sam asked > How do ADA-winning apps balance the best practices and standards in the HIG with the novelty that makes them...well...ADA-winning?

üëè Anqi
Doug L (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:21:08

*Thread Reply:* Well you hit on the two, sometimes opposing, forces that define ADA winners

Doug L (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:21:55

*Thread Reply:* In my view, an ADA winner has to embody the spirit of the HIG, even if there are details that might not conform to the letter of the HIG

Doug L (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:22:39

*Thread Reply:* But an equally important thing is the voice, or personality, of the app

ü§î Sam
Doug L (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:24:19

*Thread Reply:* The categories that we introduced last year (2021) try to add a bit more substance and clarity around the qualities that define winning apps

üëç Duncan, Sam, Linda D (Apple)
Sam
2022-06-08 19:24:42

*Thread Reply:* @Doug L (Apple) Can you elaborate on the voice/personality please?

Doug L (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:24:50

*Thread Reply:* Yeah, fair question

Doug L (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:26:07

*Thread Reply:* I guess I just see those terms as representing two things ‚Äî (1) a cohesiveness across the app ‚Äî the app feels like a single experience, and is internally consistent, and (2) the app has a character or look or feel that is memorable

Sam
2022-06-08 19:28:14

*Thread Reply:* Ohhh I think I gotcha, like how Carrot Weather uses satire and the robotic voice to strengthen the personality of the app‚Äôs narrator?

üíØ Linda D (Apple)
Linda D (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:32:28

*Thread Reply:* Yes there's being consistent with the platform experience, and then there's taking that to the next level by differentiating your app/game as a stellar example of one of our categories. That means you don't necessarily need a visually-heavy custom branded app but you offer something by way of your design/UX that sets you apart (I'm thinking Slopes here as a great example of this)

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 19:20:36

@Robert asked > Could you elaborate on any user research (quantitive or qualitative) processes the team uses to shape HIG guidelines?

‚ûï Adi, Damian
Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:21:10

*Thread Reply:* (These questions are good!)

üôå Robert, Jordan
Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:23:29

*Thread Reply:* We meet with developers to ask them for feedback on existing content (qualitative). We also regularly talk with developers throughout the year about their apps and, in those conversations, common questions come up that we realize we haven‚Äôt really answered in the HIG (or videos). So those turn into ideas about how we can improve the HIG.

Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:24:31

*Thread Reply:* And the HIG is really a massive collective effort involving design and engineering teams throughout Apple. This HIG is the product of internal experiences where people had misconceptions or questions during the design process that we anticipate designer and developers will have once we ship new features.

Robert
2022-06-08 19:27:14

*Thread Reply:* Does the team do any old school, Bruce Tognazzini-style quantitative experiments when designing new features? I‚Äôm thinking of the equivalent of Fitts‚Äôs Law, but for touch.

üëÄ Andrew, Adi
Linda D (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:44:42

*Thread Reply:* @Robert Depends on the team! We always nerded out about that and other things (catmull rom) on the Prototyping team, but other teams keep their process more intuitive/empathy-based vs. scientific

üëç Adi, Robert, Kyle

‚ûï Heidi, Marianka, Mike S (Apple), Tiago
‚ù§Ô∏è Tiago
Ben S (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:33:47

*Thread Reply:* Xcode has a built-in Color Contrast Calculator. To open it:

  1. Open the Accessibility Inspector by choosing Xcode > Open Developer Tool > Accessibility Inspector.
  2. In Accessibility Inspector, choose Window > Show Color Contrast Calculator
:gratitude_thank_you: Cristian-Mihai, Violet
üëç Cristian-Mihai, Gennadii

2022-06-08 19:34:24

*Thread Reply:* I love this one. It sits in the menu bar so you can use it anywhere. https://apps.apple.com/gb/app/contrast-color-accessibility/id1254981365?mt=12

Mac¬†App¬†Store
‚ÄéContrast ‚Äî Color Accessibility
‚ÄéMake sure the text you're designing isn't too light in your interface designs with Contrast. Combine this simple little menu bar app with your favorite design tool and design with accessibility in mind. Enter hex codes manually or use the built in color picker for sampling colors directly from your‚Ä¶
Original URL: https://apps.apple.com/gb/app/contrast-color-accessibility/id1254981365?mt=12

üëç Jessiah
Dan
2022-06-08 19:38:43

*Thread Reply:* I'm really hoping more tools start adding the LCH (lightness, chroma, hue) color space, it makes trying to keep similar contrast across different colors much easier since it (mostly) keeps the same perceptual contrast while just adjusting the hue.

Dan
2022-06-08 19:39:36

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 19:37:13

@Tyler asked > Curious what your pov is on link buttons, specifically buttons embedded within text content on native. There are some cases where this type of treatment can make sense and then others where it feels like we‚Äôre just pulling over from web. Do you have any formalized process around when to use and not use this treatment?

üòÆ Richard
üëÄ Jordan
Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:39:26

*Thread Reply:* Good question! My sense is that links inline commonly get overlooked because (a) not expected in apps and (b) the color distinction is often too subtle. In general they should be avoided. But there are cases where it can work. One that comes to mind are ‚ÄúMore >‚Äù links at the end of a paragraph of text where you navigate to a child view to see more. Or expand a partially revealed block of text.

üôå Jordan
Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:39:55

*Thread Reply:* But it‚Äôs almost always more clear to use a proper button or table row with a chevron.

üôå Jordan
Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:40:50

*Thread Reply:* Probably the biggest issue with link style buttons, especially when presented in context of other text, is that the tap target size is too small (not 44pt tall) so tapping accuracy is compromised

üôå Jordan
Tyler
2022-06-08 19:48:13

*Thread Reply:* Thanks for the response. Right, we‚Äôve certainly argued from an accessibility perspective - tap targets and contrast. The challenge is (as component devs/designers) to come up with a general alternative. We‚Äôve seen push back that there is an efficiency to associating an action with a verb in a sentence. Pulling actions out to separate buttons can end up elevating them. T&C or legal section, for example.

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 19:40:51

I am not sure it if is a combination of a segmented controls and pull-down buttons. > > Is this filtering component something that will be added to the guidelines in the near future?

*Thread Reply:* I had also noticed during the WWDC Keynote on Monday that the updated Home app on iOS adopts a similar component with different functionality. So my question expands to this as well.

IMG_1903.jpg
Doug L (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:48:09

*Thread Reply:* Ahh, I see. Toggle-able filters / buttons. Something like this may be the beginning of a pattern that is adopted across Apple apps, or these may be one-off solutions within particular apps. From a HIG POV, there is a bit of push-pull with this. If it turns into a pattern, and if that pattern is formalized as a specific element in a framework, that is typically the criteria for arrival in the HIG

üôå Damian, Marianka
Doug L (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:51:13

*Thread Reply:* This is an interesting one, though.

Doug L (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:51:24

*Thread Reply:* Thanks for raising it.

Damian
2022-06-08 19:52:39

*Thread Reply:* Appreciate the feedback on this @Doug L (Apple).

Doug L (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:52:55

*Thread Reply:* Thanks for asking, this is a fun one

Doug L (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:54:59

*Thread Reply:* Makes me realize that, for a concrete control like this, the HIG is relatively conservative; something really needs to be a component that is defined in a framework to get guidance at this level. But for bigger picture, experiential things, the HIG is a bit more predictive? Or proactive?

PJ

@Andrew asked > Any design guidelines for EDR color on Apple platforms?

Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:42:16

*Thread Reply:* Mostly we just want people to add color profiles to their images. If we could do that, it‚Äôd be a huge win.

Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:42:57

*Thread Reply:* We don‚Äôt really have guidance specifically about EDR in the HIG. Might be some good documentation elsewhere on developer.apple.com but I‚Äôm not familiar with it.

Andrew
2022-06-08 19:46:20

*Thread Reply:* Color profile tagging is critical, esp for P3! AFAIK, images with EDR profiles don‚Äôt show up in EDR across the OS, though videos do. Photos does do EDR for photos, though, so it‚Äôs clearly something where thought has gone into it.

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 19:48:26

@Dan asked > In your guidance around colors, have you all started digging into color spaces like LCH and perceptual color contrast much yet? Maybe not something you can discuss yet but it's a super interesting area and trying to choose colors with a matching human perceptual contrast across the palette is super useful and something I'd love to see Apple push as well.

Linda D (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:49:07

*Thread Reply:* I also think it's a great area to explore! I posted this in another question but the WCAG 3.0 perspective on color contrast is fascinating and something that addresses our issues with how color contrast is calculated now

üíØ Dan
Dan
2022-06-08 19:52:09

*Thread Reply:* It really is fascinating stuff. And how it's looking to take into account type size, boldness, etc. into the calculation in a much more nuanced way than just large or small type. Would be awesome to see Apple push some things like this outside of WCAG as well.

Andrew
2022-06-08 20:00:08

*Thread Reply:* eg https://blog.datawrapper.de/color-contrast-check-data-vis-wcag-apca/

Datawrapper Blog
It's time for a more sophisticated color contrast check for data visualizations - Datawrapper Blog
The WCAG contrast requirements are flawed. Here's what a new approach could mean for data visualizations.
Original URL: https://blog.datawrapper.de/color-contrast-check-data-vis-wcag-apca/

@Andrew asked > Outline views are in the HIG as being macOS only but the need for a nested outline can still occur on iOS. The HIG just says not supported but that's from a control aspect. I've implemented them by using different list cell layout to provide a nesting but would welcome other suggestions. > > https://developer.apple.com/design/human-interface-guidelines/components/layout-and-organization/outline-views

developer.apple.com
Outline views - Layout and Organization - Components - Human Interface Guidelines - Design - Apple Developer
An outline view presents hierarchical data in a scrolling list of cells that are organized into columns and rows.
Original URL: https://developer.apple.com/design/human-interface-guidelines/components/layout-and-organization/outline-views
Andrew
2022-06-08 19:54:44

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 19:57:32

@Marianka asked > Do you follow an 8-point grid? For example, Table row padding would be 16 on either side, but 44 in height? I understand tap states need to be large enough, but why not 48?

Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:58:59

*Thread Reply:* Hi @Marianka - Yes, an 8-point grid is used in many circumstances. However, there are some exceptions. For example, layout margins are 16pt in compact size class but 20pt in regular‚Ä¶. 24pt would‚Äôve been too much. Sticking at 16 would look too thin.

üî¨ Andrew
Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:59:29

*Thread Reply:* The grid is mostly about width, not height

üôå Marianka, Damian, Agatha
üìê Richard
Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-08 20:00:17

*Thread Reply:* IIRC, the decision about 44pt goes back further than the use of an 8pt grid for layout.

Marianka
2022-06-08 20:01:22

*Thread Reply:* Thanks for the insight @Mike S (Apple)!

‚úÖ Mike S (Apple)
Linda D (Apple)
2022-06-08 19:57:56

2022-06-08 20:08:14

2022-06-08 20:13:09

*Thread Reply:* Hey @Bradley! Sorry for the delay ‚Äî we had quite a few questions popping in there at the end üôÇ

Serenity C (Apple)
2022-06-08 20:18:04

*Thread Reply:* This is our first year running Digital Lounges across the majority of our teams, and we want to make sure the (very great) questions everyone has get great answers. We‚Äôre running activities at specific times to ensure that our designers can answer as many people as possible, and questions don‚Äôt fall through the cracks!

In addition, we‚Äôve got a lot of awesome other activities scheduled during WWDC, including design labs ‚Äî as much as we‚Äôd love to hang out all day with everyone here in the lounges, we want to make sure that folks who have requested 1:1 appointments get dedicated time and our designers‚Äô attention isn‚Äôt split.

Finally, we‚Äôre running some really cool design challenges over in <#C03HKS00DFT|> all week long, and we do offer open posting there from 9 - 6 p.m. PT for folks to collaborate on design ideas.

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 20:00:37

@Richard asked > With dynamic type is it expect that all text based content on the interface will scale? Is there a time where that's not appropriate such as in button containers?

Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-08 20:02:39

*Thread Reply:* Great question. It‚Äôs really not possible for ALL text to scale in some cases. Tab bars, for instance, don‚Äôt scale because text would truncate immediately which defeats the purpose. And there is an AX setting for showing the tab icon and label in a bezel on tap.

Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-08 20:03:03

*Thread Reply:* The general approach is to make sure all text in the content area / scroll views scales.

Richard
2022-06-08 20:03:36

*Thread Reply:* Awesome, thanks for the clarification Mike üëç

‚úÖ Mike S (Apple)
Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-08 20:03:37

*Thread Reply:* Text in fixed height elements (like tab / toolbars) is tricker

‚òùÔ∏è Michal
Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 20:03:53

@Leonard asked > I often struggle with trying to minimize the amount of submenus, while not making the interface look too bloated (especially since I work on photo editing apps that get somewhat complex). Do you maybe have some thoughts on how to balance those things (how many controls there should be visible at once, how many submenus deep you can go, etc)?

Doug L (Apple)
2022-06-08 20:04:37

*Thread Reply:* Hi @Leonard. Not sure whether a Slack answer will even scratch the surface of this question, but I have a couple of quick thoughts

Andrew
2022-06-08 20:06:21

*Thread Reply:* I share @Leonard's pain, having a rich document editing experience within an iPhone interface

Doug L (Apple)
2022-06-08 20:07:10

*Thread Reply:* (1) The person. Is this photo editing for ‚Ä¶ professionals? influences? some specific person? ‚Ä¶ I really would start here, even though it‚Äôs the obvious designery thing to say, because I think it helps shape what level of detail and density is appropriate

Leonard
2022-06-08 20:10:39

*Thread Reply:* It gets especially difficult when you try to cater to both, making the app easy to use while also giving advanced users more tools. But that‚Äôs for sure a good place to start, professionals are used to different kinds of UIs as well

Doug L (Apple)
2022-06-08 20:12:35

*Thread Reply:* (2) The platform will dictate your heuristics around detail and density. Designing for Mac and iPad, I would push the density, and try to deliver sets of controls as completely as possible ‚Äî i.e., i‚Äôd try to avoid submenus, and where I had them, I would try to make them ‚Äúsimilar‚Äù or at least similarly labeled across controls

üôå Leonard
Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 20:04:48

@Richard asked > How do I know when a small button is ok? üòÑ > Do I just need to ensure they have appropriate clearance of 44px all the way around to meet the guidelines?

üôå Andrew
Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-08 20:05:42

*Thread Reply:* It‚Äôs OK to have smaller button but you definitely want to have a tap area that extends to 44pts in height

Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-08 20:05:56

*Thread Reply:* So, yes, padding can be a factor

Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-08 20:06:49

*Thread Reply:* In general though, a physical background height of 44pt is a good idea. Even if the tap target is taller, users don‚Äôt know that. So they‚Äôll naturally slow down to aim accurately

üëç Richard
Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 20:04:49

@Jordan asked > Sparked by a previous thread, are yall changing any recommendations for when to use title-case vs sentence-case capitalization style?

Kathryn Y (Apple)
2022-06-08 20:06:07

*Thread Reply:* Great question! Although the guidance is to use title case in components like button labels and menu items, it also comes down to stylistic choices for the text content within your app.

üôå Jordan
Serenity C (Apple)
2022-06-08 20:11:55

*Thread Reply:* 100%, @Kathryn Y (Apple)! And when it comes to the content within your app, it ‚Äî and your style guide ‚Äî is going to evolve over time. As folks in this channel noted, we decided to move to sentence case in the HIG after many years. üôÇ The most important thing is to be consistent ‚Äî if you‚Äôre going to use title case for your content headers, make sure you‚Äôre doing that everywhere in your app. If you change that style, make sure you‚Äôre adopting it across the board. And final tip: Even if you largely follow the paradigms of a guide like AP or Chicago Style, it‚Äôs super helpful to maintain a separate personal style guide for your content ‚Äî that way, you have a great reference document.

üôè Jordan

2022-06-08 20:07:35

Familiar navigation patterns can help people easily explore the information within your app ‚Äî and save them from unnecessary confusion...

Doug L (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:02:07

üßµ In the meantime! I have a request: Let‚Äôs begin thinking about charts. What‚Äôs the most amazing chart you‚Äôve ever seen? (‚ú® Find a screenshot if you can! ‚ú®) Any charts that have made you laugh?

Lilian d (Apple)

RPReplay_Final1653577791 2.mov
‚ù§Ô∏è Lilian d (Apple), Cristina, Patricia Gabriele
Dan
2022-06-08 22:32:40

*Thread Reply:* Oooo it‚Äôs in stereo! The twitter example didn‚Äôt do that!

üòé Lilian d (Apple), Linda D (Apple)
Andrew
2022-06-08 22:40:08

*Thread Reply:* Oh yummy. Many years ago I wrote 3D stereo movie plugins for QuickTime & used audio logging that ended up sounding a lot like this as the only way to debug what was happening in the codec pipeline.

Super-short series of tones at different points of content processing provided realtime explanation of what was happening. It was all too fast for a textual console log to be useful & activated a different pattern matching area of the brain.

üôå Linda D (Apple)
üòØ Lilian d (Apple)
Andrew
2022-06-09 00:13:00

*Thread Reply:* Note that you can nearly do this in modern XCode with the Edit Breakpoints feature, except there's no choice of sounds so you are stuck with long system sounds. I was using CodeWarrior back in 2000.

Doug L (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:25:17

Don‚Äôt be shy ‚Ä¶ We‚Äôd love to hear any questions about charts or infographics.

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 22:25:50

@Martin asked > More of an abstract question: Taking the Fitness app as an example, the calendar view tends to stick out as a completely separate design pattern. Are there any guidelines on when you would want to implement charting in a calendar as opposed to a tabbed interfaced that grouped by day/week/month etc.?

Nicholas F (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:27:21

*Thread Reply:* That's a great question! The Fitness app is focused on a daily activity like closing your rings. Since this is a top-level goal of the app, the calendar view makes it easy to see your successes through time.

Nicholas F (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:28:01

*Thread Reply:* The Health app mirrors the same information but in a longitudinal form, where you can see larger trends.

Martin
2022-06-08 22:31:40

*Thread Reply:* Yup that makes sense! I guess what I'm trying to wrap my head around is finding the medium of digest-able information and too much but that's the joy of design!

Nicholas F (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:32:33

*Thread Reply:* Each of these approaches has its advantages. The calendar view excels at showing streaks and achievements relative to the day of the week. Conversely, the charts in Health aggregate away those daily details into larger trends.

Doug L (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:32:40

*Thread Reply:* Yeah, it‚Äôs interesting to me that the calendar format is sort of perfect for the Activity Rings in that they can be displayed neatly in rows / columns on a calendar grid

Martin
2022-06-08 22:38:07

*Thread Reply:* I would say the calendar is quick overview but the trends, such as in Health, is where the power of charts come in.

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 22:28:23

@Cristina asked > Is it possible to decide the number of decimals if the numbers on one of the axes are really close to each other, e.g. a range from 0 to 1 with 5 lines

Halden L (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:29:38

*Thread Reply:* A swift charts question I'm assuming! The framework can truncate labels for you to fit the space, but otherwise you could write in some logic to format the labels according to the space you have available.

:gratitude_thank_you: Cristina
Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 22:32:55

@Jake asked > What are the best practices for using color in charts (such as considering accessibility for color blindness)?

Lilian d (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:34:22

*Thread Reply:* Great question! We talk about these best practices in the ‚ÄúColor‚Äù section of our companion talk, Design and effective chart

Apple Developer
Design an effective chart - WWDC22 - Videos - Apple Developer
Learn how to design focused, approachable, and accessible charts. We'll show you how to design great charts with clear marks, axes,...
Original URL: https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2022/110340/
‚ù§Ô∏è Jake, Fabian
Lilian d (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:37:52

*Thread Reply:* At a high level, here are some key concepts to think about when using color in charts: ‚Ä¢ Use color to enhance ‚Ä¢ Consider associated meanings ‚Ä¢ Balance visual weight ‚Ä¢ Choose distinct colors ‚Ä¢ Respect system settings

‚ù§Ô∏è Jake
Lilian d (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:38:42

*Thread Reply:* You can also find general best practices around color in the Human Interface Guidelines: https://developer.apple.com/design/human-interface-guidelines/foundations/color/

developer.apple.com
Color - Foundations - Human Interface Guidelines - Design - Apple Developer
Judicious use of color can enhance communication, evoke your brand, provide visual continuity, communicate status and feedback, and help people understand information.
Original URL: https://developer.apple.com/design/human-interface-guidelines/foundations/color/
‚ù§Ô∏è Jake
Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 22:34:43

@Sam asked > Please tell me if I'm missing important nuance here but would it be fair to boil the different scales down to: > Macro scale = highlighting all regions of all marks > Medium scale = highlighting same region across all marks > Micro = highlighting a specific region of a specific mark

Nicholas F (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:36:35

*Thread Reply:* That sounds right, as long as with Micro the highlight is about a single data point (since a chart mark could represent multiple data points).

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 22:40:59

@Sam asked > What considerations should be made when designing a time-based chart like Safari's inspector timeline?

Nicholas F (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:43:36

*Thread Reply:* One of the most important considerations is that each mark has a start-time, and end-time and a duration. So it will be important to have a UI that reveals all of these pieces of data for each mark.

It was great to show non-programmers how the code execution should work. But since SwiftUI depends on state, this goes out the window. And I‚Äôm not sure if UML is the way to go either. Any comments would be appreciated, thank you!

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 22:43:28

@Axel asked > With Swift Charts, is it possible to reproduce the scrollable chart we find in Health App (where the chart is updated as we scroll the content)? I know we can use gestures on the chart to highlight some marks, but what about pan gesture?

Martin
2022-06-08 22:44:29

*Thread Reply:* There was a similar question in <#C03HX19UNCQ|> and they called out that the views would work the same, just need to give proper widths.

Halden L (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:45:13

*Thread Reply:* Hi Axel! Any Chart can be placed in a scroll view, but I'm guessing you are interested in the "pinned" Y axis behavior. You should be able to achieve this with a workaround, that is by ZStacking the Y axis on top of the scrolling chart. Please file a radar if this is a feature you want to get added to the API!

Axel
2022-06-08 22:51:34

*Thread Reply:* Thanks @Halden L (Apple). Here is the result I want.

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 22:52:05

@Jessiah asked > Is it possible to zoom in on a SwiftUI chart? I.e., pinch and zoom to see details closer up? > Could you tap on a bar (or other mark) to open a new view, for example, showing a list of the items presented in that bar?

Halden L (Apple)
2022-06-08 22:56:30

*Thread Reply:* Hi @Jessiah great questions!

(1) This might depend on what behavior you're looking for. There currently isn't a pinch + zoom API built directly into Swift Charts, but you could capture a the gesture in a chartOverlay and respond to it accordingly by manipulating the scale / data in the chart.

(2) Yes! Absolutely. Using a chartOverlay and the provided ChartProxy to read the data point being tapped.

There are some great examples of these in the Swift Charts sample app (https://developer.apple.com/documentation/charts/visualizing_your_app_s_data)

Check out the "Swift Charts: Raise the bar" talk too! Donghao explains more there. https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2022/10137/

Apple Developer
Swift Charts: Raise the bar - WWDC22 - Videos - Apple Developer
Dive deep into data visualizations: Learn how Swift Charts and SwiftUI can help your apps represent complex datasets through a wide...
Original URL: https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2022/10137/
üëç Nicholas F (Apple), Jessiah
Jessiah
2022-06-08 22:58:22

*Thread Reply:* okay awesome thank you!

Halden L (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:04:33

*Thread Reply:* you're welcome! thank you for the question

2022-06-08 22:54:22

üìä Linda D (Apple), Mike S (Apple)
üìà Lilian d (Apple)
Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-08 22:58:18

@Lior asked > is there any sense in adding animations to Charts (w/o user interaction) or its a bad practice?

üôå Halden L (Apple)
Nicholas F (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:00:10

*Thread Reply:* When used properly, animation can certainly enhance your chart‚Ä¶ even when not tied to user interaction. For example, to indicate that a chart has updated, animating a point or growing a bar can be a helpful and delightful addition.

üëç Lior, Andrew
Lilian d (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:01:42

*Thread Reply:* Note that when adding animation, it‚Äôs also important to ensure they adapt as needed for a device‚Äôs ‚ÄúReduce Motion‚Äù accessibility setting

üíØ Lior, Nicholas F (Apple)
Doug L (Apple)
2022-06-08 23:01:14

Okay, chart friends. We need to wrap it up. Thanks for joining! If you want to continue the conversation, there‚Äôs a Chart design lab on Friday. Make sure you request lab appointments with this team by Thursday at 6pm. üìà

2022-06-09 00:00:02

üëã Hi everyone, and welcome to the Design App Shortcuts! My name is Doug and I‚Äôm a Design Evangelist at Apple. Over the next hour, we‚Äôll watch Design App Shortcuts, and we‚Äôll be joined by @Lynn S (Apple),‚ú® the presenter herself ‚ú®, and @Cameron B (Apple) a designer from the Shortcuts team.

ü•≥ Linda D (Apple), Cameron B (Apple), John
üëã:skin_tone_2: Lynn S (Apple)
üëã Cameron B (Apple), Izzy Z (Apple)
Doug L (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:00:52

‚ù§Ô∏è Lynn S (Apple), Anqi

Doug L (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:03:33

Gero
2022-06-09 00:04:50

*Thread Reply:* I have a shortcut which records the length of my toothbrushing to Health. I tap it once and it adds a one minute calendar event. When tapped again it checks how long the time between event and tapping are records it to Health and removes the calendar event.

Lynn S (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:05:41

*Thread Reply:* Similarly, I have a convenient one to add water intake to the Health app!

üíß Gero, Lynn S (Apple)

2022-06-09 00:08:02

*Thread Reply:* I have one that checks the surf at a beach (with Surfline)

Sam
2022-06-09 00:29:26

*Thread Reply:* I was able to digitize my entire physical mail inbox using a shortcut I created. ‚ÄûHey Siri, scan a letter‚Äú automatically opens the camera, names the letter accordingly using OCR, and sorts it by month and date into a folder structure in iCloud. :smilingfacewith3hearts:

‚ù§Ô∏è John
Cameron B (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:24:22

*Thread Reply:* Hey @John, you can have 3 app names synonyms: https://developer.apple.com/documentation/sirikit/registering_custom_vocabulary_with_sirikit/specifying_synonyms_for_your_app_name

‚úÖ John

2022-06-09 00:32:36

*Thread Reply:* For your second question: App Name Synonym √ó Parameters √ó App Shortcuts √ó Synonyms < 1000

‚ù§Ô∏è John
John
2022-06-09 00:34:23

‚úÖ Cameron B (Apple)
Doug L (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:15:54

üßµ Refine your visuals. Engaging visuals and clear dialog are critical to creating a great App Shortcut. How can you bring key elements from your app into custom snippets?

üé® Cameron B (Apple), John, Ari W (Apple)
John
2022-06-09 00:20:04

*Thread Reply:* Does your app need to detect which device context the user is in and return a contextual response? Or would your App Intent include a supporting dialog + custom visual AND a full dialog? And then the system serves up the appropriate one based on context

Lynn S (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:25:18

*Thread Reply:* We‚Äôd encourage you to provide a custom visual, supporting dialog, and full dialog, and the system serves up the appropriate combination based on device and context.

Lynn S (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:26:01

*Thread Reply:* But as noted, you can suppress the supporting dialog if it is redundant with your custom visual

‚úÖ Cameron B (Apple)
üôå John
John
2022-06-09 00:26:43

2022-06-09 00:24:51

üßµ Last one: Make it discoverable. Helping users discover your App Shortcuts is crucial to their success! How does your app teach someone about its Shortcuts for the first time?

Doug L (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:34:14

*Thread Reply:* Hey @John ‚Ä¶ It would help to know a bit more about what you‚Äôre looking for related to Person

John
2022-06-09 00:36:05

*Thread Reply:* Lynn mentioned that using these common options has Siri NLU benefits. So i was curious what data was backing this. Does Person referred to the customer‚Äôs Contacts? Or something else

Doug L (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:37:50

*Thread Reply:* Gotcha.

üëç John
Doug L (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:38:56

*Thread Reply:* Trying to find a reference for this.

üôè John
Duncan
2022-06-09 00:40:22

*Thread Reply:* Is this section from the transcript relevant: > The App Intent framework does provide a set of common options for these open-ended requests, such as numerical values, dates, or time values. If your required parameter aligns with one of these, definitely select it. This will allow you to benefit from certain built-in dialog and visual patterns, as well as Siri‚Äôs natural language understanding as it pertains to these types of information. If not, you can use a custom entity.

‚úÖ Doug L (Apple), John
Duncan
2022-06-09 00:41:05

*Thread Reply:* I am also interested if there is anything Person related but can‚Äôt find anything in the transcript re that being a supported common option type.

John
2022-06-09 00:43:31

*Thread Reply:* here‚Äôs the screen grab where I noticed it

image.png
‚ù§Ô∏è Duncan
Michael S (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:43:56

*Thread Reply:* Here‚Äôs the documentation on IntentPerson: https://developer.apple.com/documentation/appintents/intentperson

‚ù§Ô∏è John, Duncan
üëÄ Duncan
ü§Ø Duncan
Doug L (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:44:24

*Thread Reply:* @Michael S (Apple) has entered the chat.

Michael S (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:44:26

*Thread Reply:* Siri has built in, baseline NLU for many of these types. For example, for an integer, the user might say ‚Äúone dozen‚Äù. Siri will parse this as 12 for you automatically

üî¢ Lynn S (Apple)
Michael S (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:45:30

*Thread Reply:* Similarly, for IntentPerson, Siri has some baseline understanding of what is a first name, what is a last name, etc. Siri will attempt to construct an IntentPerson for you if you do an open ended value prompt for an IntentPerson type

üëç John
Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 00:33:32

@Tyson asked > Is it still posable to have user inputs in initial Siri request for media requests?

Doug L (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:35:09

*Thread Reply:* Good question @Tyson ‚Ä¶ @Cameron B (Apple) is on it

üòÑ Tyson
Cameron B (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:35:46

*Thread Reply:* Yes, you can do an open-ended request, disambiguation, or parameter confirmation before completing your intent.

üëç Tyson
Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 00:39:37

@Duncan asked > I'm wondering what the maximum (sensible) number of values is for a parameter. In my app, users attach notes to people. It'd be great to have a shortcut for "New note for <Person Name>"... but an active user could easily have 1,000 or more people in the app that the note could be attached to... which it sounds like isn't the kind of "fixed list" you have in mind? > > So... the 20 top favorite people, or similar?

Lynn S (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:42:20

*Thread Reply:* Right, for lists of this size and for a list of contacts, you would want to use an open-ended request, which would also allow you to use a person entity.

Duncan
2022-06-09 00:43:30

*Thread Reply:* Ok right, thanks.

Lynn S (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:44:02

*Thread Reply:* It wouldn‚Äôt be suitable for a dynamic parameter, because those contact names would become an array of strings, which limits the flexibility people can use to ask for them.

Duncan
2022-06-09 00:48:30

*Thread Reply:* Reading in the other thread about IntentPerson parameters. For an app that has access to CNContacts, is there a way (other than matching on name) to link an IntentPerson to the CNContact that presumably underlies the source of that information?

Cameron B (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:49:46

*Thread Reply:* @Michael S (Apple) can you take this?

Michael S (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:53:58

*Thread Reply:* right now you‚Äôll need to match on name. Please file a feedback request! We‚Äôd like to hear about your use case and look into this more

Lynn S (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:49:22

Lynn S (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:49:51

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 00:51:53

@John asked > Could I create an iOS app that once downloaded from the App Store is never really meant to be opened by the user? Instead it would include App Intents, and primarily be accessed via Siri with just dialogs & custom snippets?

Doug L (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:55:01

*Thread Reply:* It‚Äôs an interesting question @John ‚Ä¶ It‚Äôs a paradigm we‚Äôve seen on Apple Watch with watch apps. Some watch apps are really just ways to deliver complications to the watch face, and rich notifications on the watch itself

üí° John
Doug L (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:55:45

*Thread Reply:* However, those watch apps also display the information that is delivered in the complication and notification.

üëç John
Doug L (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:56:25

*Thread Reply:* So anyway, the app matters üí™

üëç John, Wong
Cameron B (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:57:27

*Thread Reply:* But technically yes, you can build an app that‚Äôs focused on providing App Shortcuts, but when someone taps on your app icon you‚Äôll still have to have a viable experience that explains what it does.

Also, if you support dynamic parameters, your app will need to be be opened for you to update the order.

John
2022-06-09 00:58:32

*Thread Reply:* So I could make an app that‚Äôs intended primarily as a container for Siri first App Intent interactions, and the app itself could just provide some context that explains the Siri functionality?

Cameron B (Apple)
2022-06-09 01:00:43

*Thread Reply:* You can build that, but if you want to manage your dynamic parameter and people are never opening your app (because it doesn‚Äôt have functionality in itself), you won‚Äôt be able to re-order or update your parameter values.

John
2022-06-09 01:01:57

*Thread Reply:* Got it, that makes sense. I‚Äôm just trying to get a mental model for what‚Äôs the minimum viable app to create for Siri! This was so helpful

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 00:52:13

@Anqi asked > How to create a timer shortcut with shorter phrase for our app if the system already have one, for example, Set a timer for 5 mins, how can we tell the system to use our app to setup the timer instead of the system clock app.

Lynn S (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:53:43

*Thread Reply:* Notably, App Shortcuts will need to include your app name, so that will help distinguish your phrases from standard Siri phrases. (i.e. ‚Äústart a <app name> timer.‚Äú)

Lynn S (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:53:52

*Thread Reply:* With a particularly strong brand, you may even be able to skip the word timer. (i.e. ‚ÄúStart a Super Special Countdown‚Äù, assuming ‚ÄúSuper Special Countdown is the app name)

üëè Anqi
Lynn S (Apple)
2022-06-09 00:55:06

*Thread Reply:* A note though! You wouldn‚Äôt want to use ‚Äúfor <time value>‚Äù in your invocation phrase, because there are infinite possible replies. That‚Äôs better as an open-ended request, for a Duration

Duncan
2022-06-09 00:58:37

*Thread Reply:* @Lynn S (Apple) I want to check I understand this. Is the distinction here that ‚Äúopen-ended requests‚Äù are always by definition follow-up requests after the invocation phrase? I wasn‚Äôt clear on this till now.

Lynn S (Apple)
2022-06-09 01:00:08

*Thread Reply:* There are a few different types of follow-up requests after the invocation phrase, and open-ended requests are one of them. Others are parameter confirmation, intent confirmation, and disambiguation.

Lynn S (Apple)
2022-06-09 01:00:18

*Thread Reply:* But these are distinct from the dynamic parameter that you provide as part of your initial invocation

üëç Cameron B (Apple)
üëç:skin_tone_3: Duncan
