Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 19:04:25

@Christian asked > Working on the prototyping team seems like such an incredible thing to be a part of. Can you tell us about your journeys to becoming prototypers at Apple? And what do you look for in potential candidates for your team?

üëç Sharmendra, Willey
Julian M (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:05:51

*Thread Reply:* A lot of us some mix of backgrounds that don‚Äôt fit neatly into the typical design / engineering teams.

Christian
2022-06-09 19:07:09

*Thread Reply:* Are there a lot of folks on the team who have a hard time identifying themselves as either designers or engineers, but actually both?

Julian M (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:07:29

*Thread Reply:* I taught myself programming outside of school and dabbled in a number of open source projects and the like. Realized I enjoyed psychology / cognitive science to learn more about how people think and approach technology. Studied Cognitive Science, HCI, and Communication Design in school. Had some design jobs but eventually accidentally found this team where I got to use my programming skills too!

Christian
2022-06-09 19:08:02

*Thread Reply:* That‚Äôs amazing, thank you for sharing Julian üôÇ

Chang
2022-06-09 19:08:13

*Thread Reply:* That‚Äôs amazing!

Marisa L (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:08:52

*Thread Reply:* A teammate was at an HCI conference (TEI '17) in Japan that I happened to have work in. He passed on my name to the recruiter. I studied Design and HCI in school, and then I interviewed!

Christian
2022-06-09 19:10:39

*Thread Reply:* That‚Äôs awesome, Marisa!

Guillaume A (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:11:10

*Thread Reply:* I studied computer science, spent some time in HCI academia, and worked for a few startups before joining Apple. For me making delightful interactive things has always been a single pursuit, and the boundaries between things like ‚Äúdesign‚Äù and ‚Äúengineering‚Äù never made too much sense to me. My teammates will have different answers but when I look at candidate portfolios, I like to see inspiration from fields beyond design & tech, a general sense of curiosity and playfulness‚Ä¶ and just weird, unexpected, unique things! (even if they‚Äôre not the most polished)

üòÑ Mike S (Apple), Linda D (Apple), Yunson
Christian
2022-06-09 19:12:03

*Thread Reply:* I completely agree, Guillaume. And I super appreciate you all taking the time to answer. Thank you!

Myl√®ne D (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:22:31

*Thread Reply:* I was a fresh graduated from ECAL in Lausanne Switzerland, where I studied interaction design. A few months after that, Jeff our current Manager saw my bachelor graduation project on a blog and then reached out. It was such a suprise! I was super excited and curious to know more about the team and I end up joining in 2018. It was great that even though I had not much professional experience, the team was interested in my portfolio. When we are looking at candidate, I think we are interested about ideas and how the candidate communicates them, even if you have short resume like I did back then.

üÜí Heidi, Linda D (Apple), Leonard, Ran, Yunson, Sean
Christian
2022-06-09 19:25:06

*Thread Reply:* Thank you @Myl√®ne D (Apple)! That‚Äôs super inspiring to read!

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 19:05:03

@Jay asked > Hey team! Im curious, when first designing a prototype of a new product, what would you say the ratio is of looks to functionality? Are looks secondary or are they the focus from the get go? Thanks :)

Guillaume A (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:10:15

*Thread Reply:* I think the main thing is to think about what questions you are trying to answer by building one (or several) prototypes. Are they questions of technical feasibility, product usefulness,‚Ä¶? etc. Looks for the sake of looks are rarely worth spending lots of early prototyping time on, but sometimes different aesthetic directions or visual metaphors are definitely things you want to prototype!

Julian M (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:12:49

*Thread Reply:* I‚Äôd add that the key balance to strike in prototyping is to make the least amount you need to make to still learn something. Sometimes that means things have to look very real so that you don‚Äôt distract from the part you‚Äôre trying to learn.

Jay
2022-06-09 19:14:05

*Thread Reply:* Interesting, forsure functionality and user experience is so important - although I do find myself holding my AirPod Max‚Äôs and just staring at how beautiful they are more then I listen to music ü§£

Do you guys have separate teams for functionality and then a team for looks, or is it all entwined?

Chang
2022-06-09 19:14:51

*Thread Reply:* @Julian M (Apple) haha, sometimes when I‚Äôm prototyping/evaluating a feature, I‚Äôll find some unrelated annoyances, and I HAVE TO FIX it.

üòÜ Julian M (Apple), Linda D (Apple)
Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 19:08:35

@Kevin asked > The Fake it Till You Make It Talk from WWDC 2014 was incredibly influential in me becoming a designer (also now have fond memories of toast). What has inspired you to join the Prototyping Team / what continues to motivate you?

‚ù§Ô∏è Andrew, Linda D (Apple), Nico, Alberto, Tiago, Serenity C (Apple), Julian M (Apple), Vidit

Andrew
2022-06-09 19:16:42

*Thread Reply:* You can get a set of templates for Keynote https://keynotopia.com/ or the ones on https://developer.apple.com/design/resources/

Keynotopia | iOS, Android and Web Prototyping UI Kits for Keynote and PowerPoint
Keynotopia UI Design Templates for Keynote and Powerpoint
Design mockups, wireframes and interactive prototypes using Keynote and PowerPoint + UI Kits for iPad, iPhone, Android, Mac, Windows, Facebook and Web
Original URL: https://keynotopia.com/
Apple Developer
Apple Design Resources
Design apps quickly by using Sketch and Photoshop templates, plug-ins, and preconfigured UI elements.
Original URL: https://developer.apple.com/design/resources/
Julian M (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:28:22

*Thread Reply:* We‚Äôve used SwiftUI a little bit, yes. We still use Keynote a lot though!

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 19:11:32

@Sam asked > How does your team go about quickly prototyping advanced interactions? I have lots of ideas for interactions I want to test but I feel my momentum is burnt out by the time I get everything set up in, say, a SwiftUI project.

Julian M (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:15:09

*Thread Reply:* Finding a way to fake it! We talk about this in most of our old WWDC sessions, but Prototyping for AR (2018) has some good examples of finding clever ways to prototype that don‚Äôt involve code at all.

Julian M (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:16:17

*Thread Reply:* There are ways to fake things with paper printouts, or with clever video capture. But often doing some simple Keynote animations can teach a lot too.

‚ù§Ô∏è Sam, Yunson, Alberto
Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 19:11:37

@Matt asked > What types of products do you prototype, what's the process of making a design, and how many rough drafts do you usually have before finalizing anything?

Guillaume A (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:18:10

*Thread Reply:* Anything that Apple has shipped and might ship is the sort of thing we prototype! üôÇ I personally have worked a lot on cameras (iPhone, iPad) and Ô£øPencil over the years, as well as Ô£øWatch and Health related features more recently. The process of making a design is generally making something, showing it to people, and learning from their feedback, and doing it over and over again. We've given a few WWDC talks on that topic over the years! We don't really count how many "drafts" we make, but everything we work on undergoes many, many iterations.

ü•≥ Linda D (Apple), Thiago, Vidit
üëè Ryan
Matt
2022-06-09 19:21:58

*Thread Reply:* Are there differences between the final product hardware and software, or are the prototypes meant to test a specific feature and include some hardware and software features, but not all of it? aka. are you trying to test something with the mindset of a customer, or as a engineer?

Julian M (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:30:52

*Thread Reply:* The mindset of a customer, or a person using the product or feature. We collaborate closely with engineering teams that figure out feasibility. Our prototypes help them understand which use cases need to be supported.

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 19:11:46

@Ryan asked > When creating prototypes, how extensively do you test it? i.e. Is it used only within the direct team or do you take the prototype to broader teams to test as well?

Guillaume A (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:12:26

*Thread Reply:* Definitely show it to broader teams. It's less about testing in a traditional, thorough sense, and more about getting lots of people from different backgrounds to try it and tell us what they think.

üëå Mika, PJ
Ryan
2022-06-09 19:14:35

*Thread Reply:* Thanks @Guillaume A (Apple) üôå If I may ask a follow up question, what kind of feedback are you looking for when testing the prototype?

Guillaume A (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:22:07

*Thread Reply:* We always build a prototype to answer questions, so what we're looking for will be about what that specific prototype is trying to answer. For example, when we were working on Scribble for iPad & Pencil, we wanted to really understand how people reacted to their handwriting being converted to digital text, what made that process more clear/understandable, what sorts of input would lead to confusion situations, and so on.

Ryan
2022-06-09 19:23:56

*Thread Reply:* Awesome, thanks for the insight üí°

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 19:12:02

@Philip asked > What are some of the tools you use for prototyping?

Guillaume A (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:15:06

*Thread Reply:* As far as digital tools I personally use Sketch and Keynote a lot for static/2D interfaces, After Effects for animation, and Swift/UIKit/Core Animation/Metal when I need to make things a bit more real/custom or interface with hardware. But everyone on our team uses different tools and has workflows that work for them.

‚ù§Ô∏è Philip, Tiago, Deanna, Vojtƒõch, Yunson
üíé Heidi, Tiago, Deanna, Vojtƒõch, Yunson, Artyom
Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 19:12:05

@Sam asked > The devs behind one of the ADA winners this year, Not Boring Habits, wrote a really interesting blog post (https://www.andy.works/words/the-future-of-design-tools)|https://www.andy.works/words/the-future-of-design-tools) about the future of prototyping/design tools, arguing for a shift from flat tools like Figma to rich, 3D-first tools like Unity and SceneKit. Do you see those tools becoming first-class citizens in a prototypers toolkit in the future?

Marisa L (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:14:22

*Thread Reply:* Hi Sam! Making in the medium the design is meant to be in is important! For a prototype seeking to answer an interaction design question, interactive prototypes are essential. For the design of a graphic poster, print out poster iterations.

Marisa L (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:15:15

*Thread Reply:* If the end artifact is meant to be spatial, then making in 3D is essential too

Marisa L (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:16:15

*Thread Reply:* I'd say there's an underlying principle that the medium that one makes/prototypes in is also a very intentional choice, and should be chosen to best align with the desired end artifact

‚ù§Ô∏è Sam, Linda D (Apple), Heidi, Yunson

üôå Armand
Marisa L (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:18:11

*Thread Reply:* I love sketching on my iPad. Note taking and drawing in meetings is important to me.

üëç:skin_tone_2: Heidi

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 19:17:41

@Sam asked > How do you go about adding (magic || whimsey || delight) to a prototype? I feel a lot of my designs lack that extra ‚ú® to make a great experience.

üôå Andrew
Julian M (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:20:01

*Thread Reply:* Give yourself time to not worry so much about solving the problem. ‚ÄúWhat other ideas does this give us?‚Äù can mean completely unrelated things. But if they seem interesting they‚Äôre worth trying. Those weird-but-interesting ideas can inspire us to connect the weird / whimsical inspiration to something that actually does solve the problem.

üíú Linda D (Apple), Sam, Christian, Philip, Barbara, Yunson
‚ù§Ô∏è Mike S (Apple), Jorge, Linda D (Apple), Yunson
Linda D (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:23:28

*Thread Reply:* well said ü•≤

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 19:17:54

@Damian asked > What tool would you suggest for rapid prototyping?

Guillaume A (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:19:19

*Thread Reply:* Whatever you're most comfortable with will be what lets you try things rapidly! For some people that's code, others animations in a tool like After Effects... to get started it's really about what you're able to quickly be productive with.

üëç Damian
üôå Tiago
Damian
2022-06-09 19:22:47

*Thread Reply:* Thanks for the feedback @Guillaume A (Apple) üôå

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 19:20:51

@Mika asked > When testing with people, how often do you change the prototype in between sessions, or not at all? i.e picking up issues from the first session and adjusting it before the next session. Is this recommended or should we stick to one prototype throughout?

Julian M (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:24:34

*Thread Reply:* We try to keep more than one direction open at a time. It might mean having multiple very different prototypes, or one prototype than has sliders / prefs and can be adjusted. If someone gives us good feedback, we incorporate it or try it out. If it‚Äôs in conflict with the previous direction, we keep both around to let people compare.

Mika
2022-06-09 19:36:36

*Thread Reply:* That‚Äôs great - thanks Julian. It makes sense to let people interact with different prototypes and observe, if I may ask, how flexible do you make prototypes? Are people allowed to tap on anything interactive on the screen, or is it limited to one flow?

Julian M (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:52:23

*Thread Reply:* It‚Äôs usually very limited. We make it look like everything‚Äôs there, but only certain parts will be functional. It‚Äôs important that the rest look real because it‚Äôs often in the whole context of a product that we learn the most.

Mika
2022-06-09 20:08:17

*Thread Reply:* Thanks Julian.

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 19:21:07

@Nico asked > When you're prototyping new ideas that are likely to meet some resistance (touch bar or dropping headphone jack), what process, if any other than just gut, do you have to decide whether to ship it or kill it?

Guillaume A (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:26:58

*Thread Reply:* Generally our team doesn't get to decide whether to ship or kill things. Our job is to explore (by making prototypes) + document all the possible directions that seem interesting or plausible for a specific topic, share with relevant teams, and see what the reactions are. It happens that something we're very excited about is not something that makes it out the door for some reason, in those cases we tend to keep bringing it up in future work that touches on that concept, and work with teams inside the company who are excited about it too to try to build momentum together.

üôå Linda D (Apple)
üëå Nico, PJ
Nico
2022-06-09 19:29:13

*Thread Reply:* Very insightful thanks

PJ
2022-06-09 19:31:01

*Thread Reply:* Cool

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 19:21:15

@Alberto asked > A question about tools: I'm a UX/UI designer who mostly use Sketch and Figma to prototype apps mockup, but recently I have discovered SwiftUI as an alternative to make high fidelity prototypes, do you think it's worth learning to program just enough to prototype better? Which tools your team use?

‚ù§Ô∏è Tiago
Andrew
2022-06-09 19:24:37

*Thread Reply:* Alberto, you just described the founding philosophy of Meng To over at https://designcode.io/

&nbsp;
Design+Code - Learn to design and code React and Swift apps
Learn design and code by building real apps with React and Swift. Complete courses about UI design, web and iOS development using Figma, CSS, React Hooks and SwiftUI.
Original URL: https://designcode.io/
Linda D (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:36:58

*Thread Reply:* @Guillaume A (Apple)?

Guillaume A (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:40:05

*Thread Reply:* Haha, the question of "should designers learn to code" is an eternal one... long answer short, I think code should be seen as one more tool in your toolbox. If you feel like it might let you make things you couldn't make otherwise, and you're drawn to it, then go for it! SwiftUI is the easiest to learn it's ever been üôÇ And Meng's website is great!

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 19:24:24

@Andrew asked > MagicMove in Keynote lets you prototype a lot of simple animations - do you have preferred animation prototyping tools? > > One of my gripes about most "modern" tools is they stop short of helping with animation handover or code generation, if they have any animation at all.

Marisa L (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:27:06

*Thread Reply:* AfterEffects has been my go to (light scripting, integration with C4D, able to combine with footage, I end up doing a lot of green screening)

Marisa L (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:28:20

*Thread Reply:* Recently got excited about a library that makes Unity's interface more like a traditional-timeline-animation-style ui

Marisa L (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:29:54

*Thread Reply:* I understand and commiserate with your gripes about modern animation tools though. I have to pull up Grapher and just fiddle with my equations (when transitioning to code)

Marisa L (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:31:24

*Thread Reply:* (so happy you mentioned magic move in keynote though! Early decks where we try to cover as many ideas as possible, going for breadth, there's plenty of keynote animations for our light sketches)

üôå Andrew
Andrew
2022-06-09 19:33:12

*Thread Reply:* I'm a big fan of https://createwithflow.com/ who generate code from visually-designed animations. Supernova Studio was another doing similar things but they pivoted off to design system management

Flow
Flow - Beautiful Animations Made Easy.
Professional Animation Software, for iOS, Web and Lottie. Import from Sketch or Figma, animate with our powerful timeline editor, generate production-ready media or code your devs will love to work with.
Original URL: https://createwithflow.com/
üëÄ Leonard
Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 19:24:26

@Jay asked > How long does it usually take from the first in hand prototype to the final polished version?

Julian M (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:27:08

*Thread Reply:* Because we‚Äôre often working with new hardware features: Years! The shortest turnaround we‚Äôve had on a project has been about two years. Some other projects we‚Äôve worked on have been on the order of seven years.

ü§Ø Christian, Linda D (Apple), Jay, Andrew, Ran, Leonard
Jay
2022-06-09 19:33:52

*Thread Reply:* @Julian M (Apple) Can I ask what that two year project was? üëÄ

Linda D (Apple)

ü§£ Jay, Maxim
üëç Jay
‚ù§Ô∏è Julian M (Apple)
Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 19:24:32

@Cristian-Mihai asked > Hi there! It's really nice to meet the prototyping team. Do you have any tips on prototyping? (best practices, stages of prototyping, and anything else you would consider important)

Myl√®ne D (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:32:39

*Thread Reply:* Always remember what are you building a prototype for, what are you trying to answer. We can get caught up sometimes in trying to have a very polish prototype but it should always be about quickly and efficiently testing a panel of different ideas. Sometimes it helps to just use low tech tools, quickly sketch things on paper, get away from screen.

üíØ Linda D (Apple), Cristian-Mihai, Tiago, Lexline, Damir
üëç Cristian-Mihai, Lexline, Bos
üëç:skin_tone_2: Heidi
Cristian-Mihai
2022-06-09 19:33:10

*Thread Reply:* Thank you!

Myl√®ne D (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:34:26

*Thread Reply:* Our team like to repeat the process of: make things -> show to people -> get some feedback and repeat until it the experience feels good!

üôå Cristian-Mihai, Tiago, Lexline, Damir, Barbara
üôå:skin_tone_2: Heidi
Cristian-Mihai
2022-06-09 19:35:36

*Thread Reply:* Sounds like a great process to follow!

Tiago
2022-06-09 19:37:11

*Thread Reply:* Great advices @Myl√®ne D (Apple) üôå thank you üôè

üíØ Heidi, Cristian-Mihai
üëç Myl√®ne D (Apple)
Cristian-Mihai
2022-06-09 19:38:52

*Thread Reply:* Yeah, thank you for this great advices!

Cristian-Mihai
2022-06-09 19:40:00

*Thread Reply:* I really appreciate it. Having the opportunity to talk to Apple‚Äôs Prototyping team is amazing!

‚ù§Ô∏è Myl√®ne D (Apple)
Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 19:29:51

@Christian asked > Do your prototypes sometimes lead to product ideas that Apple pursues, or is the context of your prototyping often within the confines of product ideas that already exist?

Julian M (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:33:23

*Thread Reply:* It‚Äôs often the opposite direction ‚Äî we‚Äôre typically prototyping new products or features that in turn teach us things we could make better about existing products!

Christian
2022-06-09 19:34:45

*Thread Reply:* Ah, that‚Äôs very interesting! And when prototyping new products, is that something your team decides to explore, or do you get ‚Äúasked‚Äù to explore a certain thing?

Julian M (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:36:29

*Thread Reply:* Both. We pursue things that we think might be interesting, but we‚Äôre also keeping tabs on the possibilities that interest partner teams that are asking for our help.

üëç Christian, Philip, Barbara
Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 19:30:04

@Philip asked > What is the collaboration dynamic between the prototyping team and Design / Eng partners?

Guillaume A (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:31:54

*Thread Reply:* We work closely with them! With engineering teams to understand the technical capabilities and limitations that we are working with, and with design teams to understand the roadmap they have for their products, and what problems they're trying to solve right now. The time horizon we work on (3-5 years) is a bit longer than the one most teams operate on, so communication is key for us to be aligned.

‚ù§Ô∏è Philip, Yunson
Philip
2022-06-09 19:35:12

*Thread Reply:* If you're able to speak about it, I'd be interested to know if either of these roles ever initiate requests from the prototyping teams, or if novel / net new experiences are normally initiated by the prototyping team

Serenity C (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:41:52

<p>@Christian asked &gt; Do your prototypes sometimes lead to product ideas that Apple pursues, or is the context of your prototyping often within the confines of product ideas that already exist?</p>

Thread in <b>#design-lounge</b>
‚ù§Ô∏è Philip
Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 19:30:43

@Christian asked > I often find that because there are so many considerations to make for a design to be truly great, that can hamper my creativity and almost block me from making progress. Do you deal with similar things, and if so, how do you manage to stay creative and keep going?

Guillaume A (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:37:47

*Thread Reply:* Absolutely! I think any creative in any field suffers from the "blank page" problem... for me I find that spending time doing things not tech/design related (playing music, spending time outdoors, reading books about random obscure topics,...) will often spark unexpected connections & inspiration that somehow find their way into my work. Something a little more specific I like to do too is to dive in the history of a topic I'm working on - for example the history of human mark making & handwriting through various cultures was very inspirational when I worked on Ô£øPencil.

üíú Linda D (Apple), Christian, Serenity C (Apple), Ran, Yunson
Christian
2022-06-09 19:38:54

*Thread Reply:* That‚Äôs both reassuring and inspiring to read. Thanks @Guillaume A (Apple)!

Marisa L (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:42:11

*Thread Reply:* "too many things to consider" is totally relatable, and absolutely something present in the day to day. I have personally really enjoyed organizing and grouping ideas along a "design space", by trying to figure out what common axis the ideas might have. It helps me feel less overwhelmed, and also allows me to identify any areas I haven't considered.

üíû Ran, Yunson
Christian
2022-06-09 19:44:47

*Thread Reply:* That‚Äôs a really great idea, @Marisa L (Apple)! I suppose it‚Äôs also about sometimes just going with the flow and then reviewing and adapting the work to feedback and design principles afterwards.

The Life of a Button - WWDC18 - Videos - Apple Developer
An in-depth exploration of essential interaction, visual and sound design principles and techniques through the design of a simple button.
Original URL: https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2018/804/
Apple Developer
Prototyping for AR - WWDC18 - Videos - Apple Developer
Designing for AR can be intimidating and discovering design flaws late in the process can be costly. See how low-tech traditional...
Original URL: https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2018/808

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 19:34:35

@Daira asked > how does your design process look like? Do you take part in problem define, before you start work on some ideas? Thanks!

Julian M (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:39:07

*Thread Reply:* We try not to be too rigid. Often we are starting with a specific problem to solve, yes. But sometimes we make things just because they seem interesting, and then figure out why and what they can help solve. It‚Äôs about giving ourselves space to figure out what feels great.

Julian M (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:39:49

*Thread Reply:* We can fit both types of process into the cycle we describe in our WWDC sessions: Make things, Show them to people, Learn from their feedback.

Daira
2022-06-09 19:41:43

*Thread Reply:* sounds great! thanks

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 19:39:00

@Adi asked > Thanks for this Q/A and congrats on all the work being released this week. Part of my day to day work is taking prototypes and being able to communicate findings to groups and teams that may not have an interest in them (yet..). If you're able to share high level insight - I'm curious how the findings from your prototypes are communicated (format, findings, risks) to external teams or even execs. To some extent the prototype itself carries this weight, but in cases where not and in person communication is infrequent - I'm curious how your team tackles this :)

Julian M (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:43:22

*Thread Reply:* It‚Äôs an interesting challenge, because different people respond to different communication styles. We do have to adapt how we communicate work depending on what people are looking for.

üëç Adi, Yunson
Julian M (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:44:36

*Thread Reply:* The nice thing about a prototype that appears high-fidelity is that it lessens the amount of assumptions people are making. If it looks like a real app, but we fake one part of the interaction, we are helping to direct feedback toward the parts that seem new.

‚ù§Ô∏è Adi, Ran, Yunson
Adi
2022-06-09 19:49:19

*Thread Reply:* Thank you - that's a nice answer and an excellent point on minimizing assumptions.

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 19:39:04

@Cristian-Mihai asked > How do you come up with an idea of a product? For example, do you do brainstorming sessions? And how do you transform an idea into a prototype?

Guillaume A (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:44:42

*Thread Reply:* I think it's important to know what the biggest questions around an idea you have, because that's what you'll want to prototype first. Is it about testing the usefulness of a feature? About exploring how to best display the results from an algorithm or machine learning model? Or is it about seeing if a new gesture interaction you came up with is easy for people to understand and perform? The goal of prototypes is to answer questions before investing a lot of time into making things real (hence why it's important to keep your prototyping process light & nimble). As far as coming up with ideas... ask people questions, and listen to what they have to say!

Cristian-Mihai
2022-06-09 20:06:32

*Thread Reply:* Thank you very much!

Cristian-Mihai
2022-06-09 20:06:46

*Thread Reply:* I really appreciate your advice.

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 19:39:32

@Avi asked > How has your workflow & design reviews changed in a WFH world? What have you found works well for collaborating remotely?

Marisa L (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:45:31

*Thread Reply:* I've done much more green screening with remote work. (green screening with props and suits with OBS running the effects and compositing in realtime to a virtual camera I use in webex)

üôå Andrew
Julian M (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:47:45

*Thread Reply:* We have a lot of collaborative Keynote decks too. Even for in-hand prototypes we build we‚Äôre taking a lot more video of them that we then place in those Keynote decks.

Marisa L (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:47:46

*Thread Reply:* I'm not in a green suit day to day of course üòÖ, but I was very happy the extensive setup came in use for a project in 2020-2021. I had thought to myself "never thought I'd be grateful for webex"

üòÇ Christian, Yunson
Myl√®ne D (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:47:56

*Thread Reply:* I like how it gives more opportunity to make real life situation prototypes, because your setup is at home, and not in a studio where things are impersonal.

üíú Linda D (Apple)
üôå Karim-Pierre
Myl√®ne D (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:50:49

*Thread Reply:* It forces you to stay even more connected with your teammates, to make sure you share regularly about the work

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 19:39:37

@John asked > How do you prototype Siri experiences?

üó£Ô∏è John, Tiago
Julian M (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:41:10

*Thread Reply:* Keynote animations with audio, in short! It‚Äôs like anything else in that we‚Äôre just faking the audio response portion.

John
2022-06-09 19:42:19

Julian M (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:46:08

üëç John, Dan, Ran, Yunson
ü§ñ Andrew, Ran, Yunson
Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 19:46:08

@Sean asked > Hey! Firstly, it‚Äôs truly an honour to speak with this team and thank you for making products that impact each and every one of us each day :D As for my question, I would love to get better at design User Interfaces. What are the benefits of Sketch/Figma/etc. and would you recommend their usage? Thanks!

Guillaume A (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:48:44

*Thread Reply:* Sketch and Figma are two popular tools for UI design and prototyping, but ultimately they're just tools - they won't give you magical results on their own. If you'd like to get better at designing UIs and you're starting from scratch I'd encourage you to focus more on things like layout, type, color, interaction patterns (the Apple HIG is a great place to get started on those topics as they specifically pertain to Apple platforms! https://developer.apple.com/design/human-interface-guidelines/) than focusing on a specific tool.

developer.apple.com
Human Interface Guidelines - Human Interface Guidelines - Design - Apple Developer
Human Interface Guidelines
Original URL: https://developer.apple.com/design/human-interface-guidelines/
üôå Tiago, Yunson
Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 19:48:13

@Jay asked > I saw Julian mention the process of 'Make things, Show them to people, Learn from their feedback' and I was wondering if you've ever had a product that's had little to no changes after feedback? A product thats a hole in one? And how much does the product usually change after feedback?

Julian M (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:48:59

*Thread Reply:* Never.

Julian M (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:49:30

*Thread Reply:* If we‚Äôre not getting feedback on something, we‚Äôre just not showing it to the right people. We will eventually show it to someone who will have feedback about it (improvements or reasons why it won‚Äôt work!)

üëç Adi, Linda D (Apple), Jay, Yunson
Julian M (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:50:42

*Thread Reply:* Things change a lot between our first conception of it and what makes it out the door. That‚Äôs the fun part about working with a whole lot of people who are very talented at what they do.

Jay
2022-06-09 19:56:19

*Thread Reply:* Thanks for this insight, and thanks for these amazing products!

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 19:50:01

@Sean asked > What are some philosophies that the team adheres to when designing and prototyping things? :D

Guillaume A (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:50:11

*Thread Reply:* Make things, show them to people, learn from their feedback!

‚ô•Ô∏è Dan, Philip, Andrew, Sean, Ivan, Barbara, Yunson, Deanna
Linda D (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:51:09

*Thread Reply:* That should be a tattoo at this point!

‚ù§Ô∏è Guillaume A (Apple), Myl√®ne D (Apple), Lexline, Philip, Sean, Yunson
Myl√®ne D (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:51:57

*Thread Reply:* Fake it until you make it

‚ù§Ô∏è Linda D (Apple), Lexline, Sean, Yunson
Sean
2022-06-09 19:52:42

*Thread Reply:* @Linda D (Apple) I‚Äôm getting a WWDC tattoo in July! I‚Äôll get that phrase added for the prototyping team üòÜ

Ivan
2022-06-09 19:56:30

*Thread Reply:* > show them to people This piece is so, so important. It almost immediately pays off by helping break down assumptions and normalities established by devs and designers, and lets you see your project and tools from a new perspective. Being open and receptive to that feedback is an incredibly value experience ‚ù§Ô∏è

Marisa L (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:57:10

*Thread Reply:* Considering an interaction "Before, During, and After" (i.e. in the example of a button before people press a button, how do they know they can do it, and what it will do, during the press how do they know the action is registered and whether they need to continue pressing ( any visuals that encourage continued action would be 'feed-forward'). And afterwards, what is the feedback that ensures we know how the action went?) Julian;s 2018 WWDC talk covers this in more detail

Myl√®ne D (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:57:33

*Thread Reply:* Always bring positive feedback when sharing the work. It should never be about personal judgement but how to make your app experience better. For example: "I don't like this color" vs "I think blue instead of read would better communicate what the experience is about"

Marisa L (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:58:36

*Thread Reply:* "Always design a thing by considering it in its next larger context ‚Äì a chair in a room, a room in a house, a house in an environment, an environment in a city plan." is a quote that I think also nicely captures the spirit of always being able to step back and not design something in isolation

Linda D (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:13:53

*Thread Reply:* @Sean!!! You will absolutely need to show this to us on Twitter when you do

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 19:51:58

@Adrien asked > Favorite books?

üìö Heidi, Tiago
Guillaume A (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:54:42

*Thread Reply:* So many, I love books! We reference Tufte a lot in our studio. Some recent design books I read and enjoyed were Extra Bold https://papress.com/pages/extra-bold, and Politics of Design https://www.counter-print.co.uk/products/the-politics-of-design

COUNTER-PRINT
The Politics of Design
Many designs that appear in today‚Äôs society will circulate and encounter audiences of many different cultures and languages. With communication comes responsibility; are designers aware of the meaning and impact of their work? An image or symbol that is acceptable in one culture can be offensive or even harmful in the
Original URL: https://www.counter-print.co.uk/products/the-politics-of-design
üìö Ran
Julian M (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:56:37

*Thread Reply:* I always like The Humane Interface and The Design of Everyday Things. Been re-reading Interface Culture recently.

üëÄ Ran
Adrien
2022-06-09 20:05:02

*Thread Reply:* Interesting

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 19:52:01

@Andrew asked > How much individual work vs collaboration do you do? > Do you work together within a document, or work independently and then present that work for feedback?

Julian M (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:53:54

*Thread Reply:* Different people on the team have different preferences. But we all attend a weekly design review with the whole Prototyping team in which all our work is shared.

üìà Andrew
Julian M (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:54:47

*Thread Reply:* It helps us build a joint understanding of what a project is, even if it‚Äôs mostly one individual ‚Äúdoing the work‚Äù, we‚Äôre all helping with feedback, new ideas, and critique. The team‚Äôs brain makes the work better.

üôå Ran
Julian M (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:55:34

*Thread Reply:* Some folks on the team prefer being in collaborative documents 100% of the time. Others will just bring their individual work to design review.

üëÄ Andrew
Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 19:54:16

@Sean asked > Is there ever a time where you have to stop and refocus the vision or design? Like, if too many new ideas have been added and the original focus has been lost?

Julian M (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:57:37

*Thread Reply:* Yes, but usually not because of too many new ideas! If there are too many new ideas it means we have a lot we can try out.

Guillaume A (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:57:39

*Thread Reply:* Yes absolutely. When that happens we typically try to focus on what it was that people loved the most in that set of work. If you have dozens of things competing for your attention, focusing on the 2-3 that really seem to be winning hearts over is often a good way to move forward without getting bogged down. But sometimes you also have to accept that while you may have a bunch of kind of cool things, there's nothing in there that's a true winner. And that's okay! There's always way for those things you liked but which weren't clear winners to make their way into other work in the future.

Julian M (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:58:39

*Thread Reply:* Yeah the latter part of Guillaume‚Äôs answer was the second part of what I was going to say. If we pause a project it‚Äôs because we feel we‚Äôve thoroughly explored a space and we just haven‚Äôt hit on what feels great.

üß† Andrew
Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 19:55:05

@Christian asked > You mentioned not being too rigid on your team and often times working on things in the span of several years. Do you have any rituals as a team to stay connected and get into a "let‚Äôs make some awesome things!" mode?

üôå Sean, Andrew, Tiago, Yunson
Christian
2022-06-09 19:56:39

*Thread Reply:* Maybe this is already somewhat answered in , but perhaps there‚Äôs some additional thoughts around team rituals that you could reflect on here?

} Julian M (Apple) (https://wwdc22.slack.com/team/U03J52JBK0C)
<p>Different people on the team have different preferences. But we all attend a weekly design review with the whole Prototyping team in which all our work is shared.</p>
Original URL: https://wwdc22.slack.com/archives/C03H77GM1NW/p1654797234259859?thread_ts=1654797121.173549&amp;cid=C03H77GM1NW
From a thread in <b>#design-lounge</b>
Guillaume A (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:59:25

*Thread Reply:* Yes, as Julian said we have weekly team meetings and design reviews where we share very openly what we're working on. Those have happened every week as long as the team's been around, over 15 years now. I think being a small tight knit team is essential to our success.

üôå Ran, Christian, Yunson
Julian M (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:00:30

*Thread Reply:* And in those design reviews we‚Äôre very open (and excited) to see random things people made that aren‚Äôt directly related to current/ongoing projects.

‚ò∫Ô∏è Ran, Yunson
Christian
2022-06-09 20:01:31

*Thread Reply:* This is so awesome and inspiring! Thanks so much for sharing!

Andrew
2022-06-09 20:01:38

*Thread Reply:* How do you scale a weekly meeting as the team / scope grows?

Guillaume A (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:03:44

*Thread Reply:* We'll have smaller, more focused meetings for individual projects. The goal for the team meetings is for the whole team to see what's going on that week, but they're not exhaustive. Our team has never been bigger than ~12 people, which I think is a feature.

üëç Christian, Andrew, Ran, Yunson
Andrew
2022-06-09 20:05:16

*Thread Reply:* I with you on keeping things small‚Ä¶ let‚Äôs just say that‚Äôs a rarity in my experience ü¶Ñ

Linda D (Apple)
2022-06-09 19:56:17

5min left of the Q&A folks! We'll close the workflow then but the team will still try to answer the questions submitted by then. And holy cowdog these questions were GREAT üéâ

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 19:58:16

@Ivan asked > Hello again, and thanks for your time! I am looking for general design guidelines on building out visuospatial metaphors in a 3D + AR environment. I have a project, github.com/tikimcfee/LookAtThat, that renders and visualizes an entire code base at once, but there's just so much to see, it gets cluttered and overwhelming! I would really appreciate some time to talk and think about what kinds of things can be presented, hidden, animated, and made otherwise visually appealing for users, such that the tool is less burdensome, and more useful. Cheers!!

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 20:00:11

@Adi asked > What are some non-digital sources of inspiration for each of ya? Books, music, art, something that you aspire to perhaps.

Marisa L (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:03:38

*Thread Reply:* Ah. So many things, how does one dimension reduce to answer this? haha, everything from me spending too much time on a saturday morning brunch watching caustics, of light going through different glassware, to thursday night Exploratorium trips, adoring Tokuujin Yoshioka's installation work, Olafur Eliasson,

‚ù§Ô∏è Adi, Linda D (Apple), Ran, Yunson

2022-06-09 20:04:53

üôå Adi, Yunson

2022-06-09 20:05:37

*Thread Reply:* See some fine art in museum is always inspiring! But yeah so many things. For me, just taking long walk randomly in San Francisco can help my thoughts wander in unexpected places.

‚ù§Ô∏è Adi, Yunson

2022-06-09 20:09:19

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 20:00:53

@Jay asked > How accurately does the original design idea translate to the prototype? Are there many changes? I saw Jony Ive say that the best ideas come from conversation, does that continue through the prototype stage?

Julian M (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:02:55

*Thread Reply:* The purpose of prototypes is to help advance the conversation. Instead of going in circles verbally about what might be, we start to talk about what‚Äôs in front of us. Or what could be in front of us that we haven‚Äôt made yet!

üëç Christian, Jay, Ran, Andrew, Yunson
Julian M (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:03:31

*Thread Reply:* Which is to say, we often find the things we think are interesting change dramatically once we have a few prototypes in front of us. And we have conversations about that!

üëç Christian, Jay, Ran, Andrew, Yunson

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 20:04:00

@Heidi asked > Do you differentiate between designing user interfaces and prototyping? Are they related or separate focuses?

Guillaume A (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:08:26

*Thread Reply:* Yes they are definitely 2 different things, although for us they overlap a lot! I think prototyping in general refers to building artefacts quickly to answer questions that will then inform how to build something "for real". So Apple also has silicon prototypers working on the M series chips, for instance! For us, we prototype interactions and user interfaces, which means we try to explore what new modes of input or new capabilities (think for example something like FaceID/Depth Camera, or Apple Pencil) would bring to our products, which then informs whether the company should invest the resources in actually building that hardware/product.

üíØ Heidi, Yunson, Tiago, Leonard
Myl√®ne D (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:08:43

*Thread Reply:* It depends on what the prototype is trying to answer and at what stage of the project we are. But generally a polished UI would help better communicate with other teams, make it look real.

üÜí Heidi, Yunson, Tiago
Julian M (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:09:49

*Thread Reply:* Yes to add to Myl√®ne‚Äôs answer, we often have to design user interfaces as a part of prototyping something!

üëç:skin_tone_2: Heidi, Yunson, Tiago
Heidi
2022-06-09 20:10:12

*Thread Reply:* Thanks for the answers! So sometimes it involves building a UI, but much more and not just limited to a digital UI with prototyping.

Julian M (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:10:16

*Thread Reply:* Though sometimes we can get away with re-using large parts of the existing designs.

üëç:skin_tone_2: Heidi
Julian M (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:11:42

*Thread Reply:* I‚Äôm not sure we‚Äôre necessarily doing more ‚Äî the final user interface designs require a lot of work to be designed for all the different devices, screen sizes, edge cases, accessibility cases, error cases‚Ä¶ we‚Äôre fortunate to get to pass on that until it becomes a specific issue for our concept. We build on what‚Äôs already there for those parts.

üëç:skin_tone_2: Heidi
Heidi
2022-06-09 20:15:52

*Thread Reply:* Thanks for the clarity!

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 20:04:02

@Philip asked > Have you ever had to build a new tool in order to design a new experience? Do you ever use custom or internal prototyping tools that apple makes?

Julian M (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:06:23

*Thread Reply:* Yes! And yes! The ‚Äútools‚Äù are a lot rougher than you might have in mind, but we‚Äôre often cobbling together our own sets of code to be able to try things. We don‚Äôt build it out into a generic reusable tool as much as we build the frameworks / scaffolding necessary to try out the very-specific thing we want to get into our hands.

‚ù§Ô∏è Philip, Adi, Yunson
Julian M (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:08:05

*Thread Reply:* We build what‚Äôs necessary to try the specific things we want to try. We try really hard to stay away from prematurely abstracting. It‚Äôs too easy to accidentally become a framework engineer or tools engineer when we really were just trying to try something out.

‚ù§Ô∏è Philip, Christian, Yunson
Linda D (Apple)
2022-06-09 20:19:01

üßµ Let's start with our P‚Äîfor Purpose. How do you use words to explain the purpose of your app?

üÖøÔ∏è Austin, Mike S (Apple), Lexline, Matt, Eric S (Apple), Kaely C (Apple), Sascha, Sarah M (Apple), Tiago
Doug L (Apple)
2022-06-09 22:10:45

*Thread Reply:* Tab bar labels often capture the purpose of the app, when they're done well

üëç Austin, Luka
üíØ Kaely C (Apple)
Doug L (Apple)
2022-06-09 22:11:13

*Thread Reply:* In my opinion, anyway. üòÖ

Dan
2022-06-09 22:17:11

*Thread Reply:* Seems to me that the words describing purpose of an app start on the App Store - not in your app.

Jennifer B (Apple)
2022-06-09 22:17:50

*Thread Reply:* That‚Äôs a great point. Think about the writing beyond just what‚Äôs inside the app.

Doug L (Apple)
2022-06-09 22:20:03

*Thread Reply:* It's a really good point, @Dan. By the time people are launching an app for the first time, they've already begun the experience with it, with the app name, app icon, the screenshots in the App Store, the description, etc

Dan
2022-06-09 22:21:11

*Thread Reply:* I suppose the tone of your app starts there too! That seems scary to think of how to get that to match what your app does.

Kaely C (Apple)
2022-06-09 22:22:53

*Thread Reply:* The voice should definitely feel cohesive, no matter where someone encounters your app!

Dan
2022-06-09 22:25:16

*Thread Reply:* I suppose that includes release notes - I‚Äôve really enjoyed some of the silly ones over time. Maybe resisting the urge to do that - plus I don‚Äôt think these get read a lot.

üëç Jennifer B (Apple)
Jennifer B (Apple)
2022-06-09 22:27:04

*Thread Reply:* You have to decide where you want to focus your efforts. But it‚Äôs all a reflection of your app, so release notes should at least be clear and helpful.

Dan
2022-06-09 22:29:06

‚Ä¢ Find the lightning bolt icon in the lower left ‚Ä¢ Choose "Ask a Question" ‚Ä¢ Type your question After you type them, we'll get them and reply back. (We're very excited btw, your letter emojis are cracking us up. üòÜ)

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 22:31:07

@Dan asked > I noticed you said that a destructive action should be on the left and red text. I never knew that - where is this sort of thing in the HIG?

Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-09 22:32:30

*Thread Reply:* Ooops, should‚Äôve responded with a reply. üòâ

Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-09 22:32:50

*Thread Reply:* Hey Dan, we have writing guidance sprinkled around the HIG in various locations. This guidance is on the Alerts page: https://developer.apple.com/design/human-interface-guidelines/components/presentation/alerts

developer.apple.com
Alerts - Presentation - Components - Human Interface Guidelines - Design - Apple Developer
An alert gives people critical information they need right away.
Original URL: https://developer.apple.com/design/human-interface-guidelines/components/presentation/alerts
Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-09 22:31:51

Hey Dan, we have writing guidance sprinkled around the HIG in various locations. This guidance is on the Alerts page: https://developer.apple.com/design/human-interface-guidelines/components/presentation/alerts

developer.apple.com
Alerts - Presentation - Components - Human Interface Guidelines - Design - Apple Developer
An alert gives people critical information they need right away.
Original URL: https://developer.apple.com/design/human-interface-guidelines/components/presentation/alerts
üëç Dan
Eric S (Apple)
2022-06-09 22:32:19

*Thread Reply:* > Identify destructive buttons. If an alert button results in a destructive action, like deleting content, specify the destructive button style to help people recognize it.

Dan
2022-06-09 22:35:32

*Thread Reply:* Oh - that is a type of button in SwiftUI?

Doug L (Apple)
2022-06-09 22:37:47

*Thread Reply:* Yep, there's more about it here: https://developer.apple.com/documentation/swiftui/buttonrole/destructive

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 22:32:56

@Ran asked > Other than users and learners, any other suggestions for referring to the people using our apps?

Jennifer B (Apple)
2022-06-09 22:34:19

*Thread Reply:* What is your audience? We often just use ‚Äúpeople‚Äù but if you can be more specific, like ‚Äúfamily member‚Äù or ‚Äúsubscriber‚Äù that‚Äôs a good way to go.

Kaely C (Apple)
2022-06-09 22:34:50

*Thread Reply:* Think about what people using your app would call themselves.

üíØ Dan
Kaely C (Apple)
2022-06-09 22:36:30

*Thread Reply:* We try to avoid the word ‚Äúusers‚Äù when we refer the people who use our apps, and prefer something that sounds more human, like "artists", "collaborators", "participants", etc. depending on the app and what people are trying to do. üôÇ

Ran
2022-06-09 22:38:09

*Thread Reply:* Thank you! That is very helpful ‚ò∫Ô∏è

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 22:35:06

@Yunson asked > Are there any examples of combining different tonalities within one app? Or should one just stick to one?

Eric S (Apple)
2022-06-09 22:36:42

*Thread Reply:* The voice of your app is something you want to remain consistent, so that folks get consistent messaging inside your app. But, as you point out, the tone can certainly modulate. When you welcome somebody, you might sound excited. But when that person has a credit card declined, you may want to sound more serious.

Kaely C (Apple)
2022-06-09 22:37:20

*Thread Reply:* Similar to how your voice is always you, but your tone changes depending on context and who you're talking to.

Eric S (Apple)
2022-06-09 22:37:34

*Thread Reply:* In other words (no pun intended, hiyooo!), it's very common ‚Äî if not important ‚Äî to adjust your tone throughout your app. The tone should reflect the situation.

Eric S (Apple)
2022-06-09 22:39:11

*Thread Reply:* As an example, coaching from the Activity app on Apple Watch is celebratory when you close a ring. But it's more matter-of-fact if your progress is lacking.

Yunson
2022-06-09 22:39:15

*Thread Reply:* Right, there is a clear distinction between voice and tone, thanks for answering both of you! And I loved your pun @Eric S (Apple) üòÇ

‚úÖ Mike S (Apple)
üôå:skin_tone_3: Mike S (Apple)
üôè Eric S (Apple)
üôå Sarah G (Apple)
üôå:skin_tone_2: Serenity C (Apple)
Dan
2022-06-09 22:49:07

*Thread Reply:* Hmmm - I guess I‚Äôm still struggling with tone vs voice - Carrot weather has insults woven into weather forecasts. Is that voice? Maybe it doesn‚Äôt have a tone. I‚Äôve never bought it because I didn‚Äôt like whatever it was

Yunson
2022-06-09 23:02:40

*Thread Reply:* I don't think these rules apply to Carrot Weather App üòÇ

Sarah G (Apple)
2022-06-09 22:39:18

Keep these good questions coming! ‚úçÔ∏è If you need ideas, ask us about best practices for writing things like onboarding, naming, navigation, buttons. Or more questions about voice and tone or accessibility.

Sarah G (Apple)
2022-06-09 22:40:45

‚ùì This one is for everyone watching and @Kaely C (Apple) and @Jennifer B (Apple), what's your favorite thing to write?

Kaely C (Apple)
2022-06-09 22:41:53

*Thread Reply:* I find it interesting to write for a subject matter I don‚Äôt know much about. I get to dive into researching a whole new area and get in the mindset of someone using that technology. It's fun to think of how to make things as clear as possible. üïµÔ∏è

üî¨ Ran
Jennifer B (Apple)
2022-06-09 22:41:56

*Thread Reply:* I really like writing setup flows. There‚Äôs a real balance between helping people get started quickly and making sure they have the information they need.

üí° Ran
Kaely C (Apple)
2022-06-09 22:43:59

*Thread Reply:* Setup flows are definitely a fun challenge! Thinking of how you introduce things simply and get someone started in the best way possible.

Dan
2022-06-09 22:44:40

*Thread Reply:* I seem to end up writing a lot of procedures for software I like to do it because future me needs these as much as others. Teaching my parents to use Apple devices is a constant challenge

Kaely C (Apple)
2022-06-09 22:47:00

*Thread Reply:* Tips and education are a big part of what we consider! But there's also the balance of not having too many modals that get in the way of the experience.

üëç Dan
Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 22:42:07

@Austin asked > How do you see the different roles of the HIG's writing guidance, and the Apple Style Guide (https://help.apple.com/applestyleguide/#/apsg1eef9171)?|https://help.apple.com/applestyleguide/#/apsg1eef9171)? Is the style guide more for contexts outside of apps and long form writing?

Eric S (Apple)
2022-06-09 22:46:58

*Thread Reply:* Great question. One way to think about it, is that your product is a major part of your brand.

With that in mind, your product may have more specific guidelines to follow so that you can make your interface feel familiar ‚Äî and subsequently, intuitive. These kinds of patterns are outlined in the the Human Interface Guidelines.

Your brand, however, may encompass more than just what appears in your product. Your website, emails, marketing collaterals, events, and even the App Store descriptions mentioned earlier, these are all examples of surfaces where your voice extends beyond your app. For us, that's where the Apple Style Guide kicks in, helping us to adhere to a wider set of grammar and syntax to ensure we have consistency at every customer touchpoint.

Think about this balance for your app, too. How can your app have clarity and consistency throughout, and how can that narrative continue outside of your app to complement what you ‚Äî and your users ‚Äî are trying to do?

‚ù§Ô∏è Austin
‚ûï Kaely C (Apple)
Eric S (Apple)
2022-06-09 22:49:22

*Thread Reply:* HIG ASG ü§ù continuing the conversation

ü§Ø Austin
Austin
2022-06-09 22:52:12

*Thread Reply:* I think the ASG should be more visible! For some reason it's hidden from search engines.

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 22:43:58

@Sean asked > Great session! So many useful tips I am 100% gonna apply to my apps. Just wondering though, would you recommend Onboarding for apps? I‚Äôve heard before it interrupts the user‚Äôs usage of the app, but I‚Äôve also heard that it makes users feel more welcome. What do you think? Thanks üòÄ

‚ù§Ô∏è Kaely C (Apple), Jennifer B (Apple)
‚ûï Lexline, Jennifer B (Apple), Austin
Doug L (Apple)
2022-06-09 22:44:43

*Thread Reply:* This is such a good question @Sean

Doug L (Apple)
2022-06-09 22:45:41

*Thread Reply:* I don't think there's a single answer to it, but @Jennifer B (Apple) @Kaely C (Apple) and @Eric S (Apple) have some thoughts

Sarah G (Apple)
2022-06-09 22:45:55

*Thread Reply:* It's going to vary based on the complexity of your app or how simple its premise is. We find what often helps is to incorporate onboarding elements or moments into the first-time experience for someone new.

Sarah G (Apple)
2022-06-09 22:46:21

*Thread Reply:* Also great question üî•

üî• Kaely C (Apple)
Doug L (Apple)
2022-06-09 22:47:02

*Thread Reply:* Maybe I'm saying the same thing, but the best onboarding doesn't feel like "onboarding"

üëç Sarah G (Apple)
Sean
2022-06-09 22:47:46

*Thread Reply:* Thanks for answering :D so, I have an app that tracks deliveries, so should the be super simple along the lines of ‚ÄúTrack your deliveries‚Äù in large title text, maybe a little but of information, and then ‚ÄúGet started‚Äù? All in one view. Thanks üôè

Jennifer B (Apple)
2022-06-09 22:48:25

*Thread Reply:* There‚Äôs no one answer to this! My favorite onboarding experiences are the ones you do right within the app itself. Like those early levels of a game that teach you how to play it. Or a chat app that uses the chat to get you set up.

üôå Sean

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 22:47:40

@Zhang asked > Thanks for amazing advice! I wonder what the arrangement for options in an alarm means. For example putting major option on the left or top. Is it recommended to change the order, e.g. from major-on-left to major-on-right, for languages using different reading order?

Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-09 22:48:43

*Thread Reply:* Hi Zhang - Yes, typically you‚Äôd want to order more important things above or to the left of less important things. And for RTL languages, check out this page in the HIG: https://developer.apple.com/design/human-interface-guidelines/foundations/right-to-left

developer.apple.com
Right to left - Foundations - Human Interface Guidelines - Design - Apple Developer
Support right-to-left languages like Arabic and Hebrew by reversing your interface as needed to match the reading direction of the related scripts.
Original URL: https://developer.apple.com/design/human-interface-guidelines/foundations/right-to-left
üëç Zhang
Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-09 22:50:24

*Thread Reply:* Also this video: https://developer.apple.com/wwdc22/10034

Apple Developer
Design for Arabic - WWDC22 - Videos - Apple Developer
Find out how to design or optimize your app or game for Arabic. Whether you're planning a first release or improving an existing app or...
Original URL: https://developer.apple.com/wwdc22/10034
Zhang
2022-06-09 22:55:25

*Thread Reply:* Thank you for answering! Such fun designing for different cultures.

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 22:51:02

@Gary asked > For full screen modals with no interaction, is Apple's preferred dismiss control an X in a circle in the top right corner (as is referenced in the Explore Navigation Design for iOS talk) as opposed to a grab style control at the top middle (indicating to pull down to close)?

üôå Sean
üëÄ Jordan
Sean
2022-06-09 22:51:43

*Thread Reply:* Great question! I‚Äôve been wondering this myself recently üëä

Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-09 22:53:02

*Thread Reply:* Totally great question. we get it a lot. We have an answer for you in the HIG: https://developer.apple.com/design/human-interface-guidelines/components/presentation/sheets

developer.apple.com
Sheets - Presentation - Components - Human Interface Guidelines - Design - Apple Developer
A sheet helps people perform a scoped task that‚Äôs closely related to their current context.
Original URL: https://developer.apple.com/design/human-interface-guidelines/components/presentation/sheets
üôå Gary
Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-09 22:53:10

*Thread Reply:* Position Done and Cancel buttons as people expect. Typically, a Done or Dismiss button belongs in a sheet‚Äôs top-right corner (in a left-to-right layout) or top-left corner (in a right-to-left layout). The Cancel button belongs in a sheet‚Äôs top-left (in a left-to-right layout) or top-right (in a right-to-left layout) corner.

Doug L (Apple)
2022-06-09 22:53:16

*Thread Reply:* Good question @Gary. This has been an interaction pattern in recent releases, moving away from the elevated sheet and toward the full-screen presentation with the close in the top right

üôå Gary
Jordan
2022-06-09 22:57:12

*Thread Reply:* Omg I LOVE that this is in the HIG now!! I literally have sent in at least 100 bug reports pointing out where the Cancel button is incorrectly located at the right. I have like 100 screenshots collected I attach to each bug report showing places where Cancel is correctly located at the left. ‚ù§Ô∏è

üí™:skin_tone_3: Mike S (Apple)
Jordan
2022-06-09 22:58:29

*Thread Reply:* It is interesting however there seems to be a bit of conflict with close buttons moving to the right recently (Safari, sheets with X instead of Cancel) ü§î

üëÄ Leonard
Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 22:51:56

@Sean asked > If you add a new feature to an app, is it a good idea to showcase that new feature when the user does a certain action (i.e. completes a task etc.) or is that bad user experience as you‚Äôre interrupting their session? Thanks üòÅ

Jennifer B (Apple)
2022-06-09 22:53:27

*Thread Reply:* This goes back to context. If that feature is relevant or helpful at that moment, then yes, go ahead and talk about the new feature. But if it‚Äôs not relevant to that moment, think about where else it would feel more contextual.

üôå Sean
Sean
2022-06-09 22:55:05

*Thread Reply:* That‚Äôs great, thanks üòä

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 22:53:08

@Austin asked > Seems common for interface copy to be too verbose before it's edited down. Are there examples that come to mind where the UI was the opposite, too terse and needed more explanation?

Eric S (Apple)
2022-06-09 22:56:51

*Thread Reply:* There are may examples of this, I'm sure. One that comes to mind is when people input personal information, like when ordering something for delivery to their home. Sure, you could just indicate that you received the information, but by restating what you received (so the customer can ensure it was entered correctly) and maybe even stating that the info won't be used for nefarious purposes (eg. it wont be sold to advertisers), you create a level of comfort that more economical language might not afford.

üëç Austin
Eric S (Apple)
2022-06-09 22:57:45

*Thread Reply:* Think about when you tell a server at a restaurant that you want a certain dish, but with extra pickles and hot sauce but no tomatoes and can you please switch the fries for a salad. Some servers won't write that down. And while that's impressive to see, it's also nice to hear when the server repeats it back to you so you know the meal will come as you asked.

:knife_fork_plate: Ran, Austin, Linda D (Apple)
Kaely C (Apple)
2022-06-09 22:59:30

*Thread Reply:* Love that metaphor @Eric S (Apple). Another thing we do often is link out to support articles for people who want to learn more about a particular subject. That way the information is there if you need, but it's not in the way.

üëç Austin
Sarah G (Apple)
2022-06-09 22:55:41

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 22:56:12

@Charlie asked > What would be the best way to dismiss a full screen modal that has content? Would it be a button along the lines of ‚ÄòDone‚Äô at the bottom, or is it still a cross in the top right as mentioned earlier?

Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-09 22:56:43

*Thread Reply:* Hi Charlie, there‚Äôs some good insights in the HIG on the Sheets and Modality pages.

Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-09 22:56:59

*Thread Reply:* https://developer.apple.com/design/human-interface-guidelines/components/presentation/sheets

Austin
2022-06-09 22:57:04

*Thread Reply:* Personally I would be reluctant to use a bottom corner in a Mac app, since you have to consider window movement and that it could be clipped by the Dock.

‚úÖ Mike S (Apple)
Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-09 22:57:16

*Thread Reply:* https://developer.apple.com/design/human-interface-guidelines/patterns/modality

developer.apple.com
Modality - Patterns - Human Interface Guidelines - Design - Apple Developer
Modality is a design technique that presents content in a separate, focused mode that prevents interaction with the parent view and requires an explicit action to dismiss.
Original URL: https://developer.apple.com/design/human-interface-guidelines/patterns/modality
üëç Charlie
Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-09 22:57:54

*Thread Reply:* Yes Austin, generally not a good idea to position controls at the bottom of mac windows.

Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-10 00:29:04

*Thread Reply:* Also, check out: https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2022/10001/

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 22:56:13

@Lexline asked > Any tips on how to position elements so as to help with functionality and design?

Jennifer B (Apple)
2022-06-09 22:57:09

*Thread Reply:* In our session, we talked about information hierarchy. As with everything it‚Äôs going to depend on the specifics, but in general, think about your headlines and buttons. Make them clear and aligned with each other.

üëç Lexline, Dan
Jennifer B (Apple)
2022-06-09 22:57:56

*Thread Reply:* Keep other text brief and easy to read. Rather than a big block of text, can you break it up into bullet points or even multiple screens?

Lexline
2022-06-09 23:02:59

Doug L (Apple)
2022-06-09 22:56:48

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 22:58:14

@Charlie asked > Should I still add an ‚ÄòAdd to Siri‚Äô button to my app with the new SiriKit/shortcuts functionality, or is it completely obsolete?

ü•≥ Sean
Doug L (Apple)
2022-06-09 23:00:11

*Thread Reply:* Good question @Charlie ... You don't need to remove it, if you've got it. But on iOS 16 forward, you can begin to move away from it by creating and supplying App Shortcuts, rather than requiring people to set them up

Charlie
2022-06-09 23:00:58

2022-06-09 23:02:02

*Thread Reply:* I think you've essentially got it, but I would watch the App Intents video and the Design App Shortcuts video as well

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 23:04:12

@Leonard asked > Sorry for joining so late! I make a photo editing app and I often wonder how I should deal with technical terms. One example that comes to mind are blend modes (screen, overlay, multiply, etc.) as those things are foreign concepts to the average person. Do you recommend sticking to such technical terms and providing explanations via graphics, for example?

Kaely C (Apple)
2022-06-09 23:05:24

*Thread Reply:* Ooh good question. It really depends on your audience - are they professional photographers? Then they might understand more technical terms. You can also help define things with secondary text.

üëç Leonard
Leonard
2022-06-09 23:06:43

*Thread Reply:* Thanks for the reply! The app is not targeted at professionals, so I‚Äôve tried to find ways to better communicate what those tools do

Jennifer B (Apple)
2022-06-09 23:07:10

*Thread Reply:* If these are terms of art, and it sounds like they are, it can be best to stick with them. Avoid jargon, or making up terms that might end up confusing everyone. That said, if your audience is less technical, maybe define the terms so people can learn them.

üëç Leonard, Anton
Eric S (Apple)
2022-06-09 23:07:34

*Thread Reply:* +1 to what @Kaely C (Apple) and @Jennifer B (Apple) said here. We aim to democratize access to technology with much of our hardware, software, and services at Apple; so we aim to have our language be understood by as many people as possible. But with a few of our apps, we have a specific audience (eg our creator tools, like Apple Music for Artists, that focus on specific audiences), and therefore we want the language to be in the vernacular of the users‚Äîotherwise it may feel like we've shipped a watered-down professional feature.

üëç Leonard, Ran, Anton
Eric S (Apple)
2022-06-09 23:10:40

*Thread Reply:* Since it's not aimed at professionals, show it to friends (or strangers) and see if they understand what's written. And as Jen and Kaely pointed out in their talk, consider reading it out loud to yourself as well.

Leonard
2022-06-09 23:12:53

*Thread Reply:* Thanks a lot the replies! One area of iOS that just came to mind was the blur intensity adjustment in Portrait Mode. Even though it‚Äôs a feature that‚Äôs not necessarily aimed at pros, it‚Äôs using f-stops as an analogy to real life photography.

Sarah G (Apple)
2022-06-09 23:06:20

ü§´ (One more update for those of you who stayed in the theater past the final credits: We'll be adding writing guidance to the recently re-designed HIG this fall. We're excited to get that to you soon.)

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-09 23:24:44

@Jordan asked > If I want to read the new HIG end-to-end, when should I plan to do that so everything will be in there? I know yall are working on more goodies.

Doug L (Apple)
2022-06-09 23:26:06

*Thread Reply:* Hi @Jordan good question. The HIG is a living document, so it‚Äôs always getting updated in big and small ways. Between now and the fall, the updates will (most likely) be small. In the fall, the bigger updates will land.

üëç Jordan, Yunson
Doug L (Apple)
2022-06-09 23:27:30

Austin
2022-06-09 23:32:06

*Thread Reply:* I think it would be great if it was clearer when there's more minor updates, like a technologies page gets added or something. Sometimes I'll discover on Twitter, but a more central diff would be nice! I can file feedback about this too.

Linda D (Apple)
2022-06-09 23:56:30

*Thread Reply:* We're already planning for changelogs in the HIG coming some time this summer!

‚ù§Ô∏è Austin
Linda D (Apple)
2022-06-10 00:00:21

We'll be watch Explore design navigation for iOS first. Afterwards, Sarah will answer any questions you may have!

Apple Developer

Familiar navigation patterns can help people easily explore the information within your app ‚Äî and save them from unnecessary confusion...

Linda D (Apple)
2022-06-10 00:12:30

üßµ Let‚Äôs talk about tabbed navigation! Have you seen the updated tab bar page on the Human Interface Guidelines? Does your app use a tab bar? https://developer.apple.com/design/human-interface-guidelines/components/navigation-and-search/tab-bars

developer.apple.com
Tab bars - Navigation And-search - Components - Human Interface Guidelines - Design - Apple Developer
Tab bars use bar items to navigate between mutually exclusive panes of content in the same view.
Original URL: https://developer.apple.com/design/human-interface-guidelines/components/navigation-and-search/tab-bars
Andrew
2022-06-10 00:13:35

Austin
2022-06-10 00:15:22

*Thread Reply:* I can wait until the Q&A after also! üòÖ

Oliver
2022-06-10 00:16:04

*Thread Reply:* Tabs are great, easy to implement and to grasp for a user. The thing that mostly confused me in the past where designers misusing these concepts, e.g. by adding an action to a tab icon.

Linda D (Apple)
2022-06-10 00:16:51

*Thread Reply:* @Oliver Totally, those are toolbars! Actions = toolbars. Navigation = tab bars

‚ûï Andrew
Sarah M (Apple)
2022-06-10 00:16:54

*Thread Reply:* If I‚Äôm understanding your question correctly, @Austin, your tabs should maintain state. They should be scrolled to the top of view on first launch and when the screen scrolls, even if a person taps another tab, the previous one should maintain state.

Oliver
2022-06-10 00:18:45

*Thread Reply:* What got lost in recent years where configurable tab bars - rarely any apps uses the system implementation anymore, rather e.g. after long-press a user can exchange the current tab content - would be cool to have system support for that!

Lior
2022-06-10 00:19:38

*Thread Reply:* Really loved the the screen tree in the session, made things super clear. @Sarah G (Apple) Great job! üëè

üëè Majo C (Apple), Linda D (Apple), Rachel, Serenity C (Apple)
üëè:skin_tone_3: Mike S (Apple)
üëè:skin_tone_2: Sarah M (Apple)
Austin
2022-06-10 00:21:30

*Thread Reply:* Thanks @Sarah G (Apple)! I mean if the user scrolls down in the active tab view, and then taps that same tab (not a different one), should it be expected that the view jumps back to the top? Just wondering because I think I've seen this happen in some apps, but in other apps nothing happens.

Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-10 00:25:57

*Thread Reply:* Yes, tapping the currently selected button in a tab bar should scroll the content view to the top. Also, tapping the status bar. But this is really a power feature. Not sure how many people are aware of this functionality.

üòÇ Sarah M (Apple), Majo C (Apple), Lexline, Vojtƒõch
üëç Benjamin
Linda D (Apple)
2022-06-10 00:24:03

*Thread Reply:* Tell them that Apple designers will be very disappointed to see a home tab in their UI ‚òπÔ∏è

Linda D (Apple)
2022-06-10 00:24:12

*Thread Reply:* And point them to this video!

Dan
2022-06-10 00:27:53

*Thread Reply:* How do you feel about a ‚Äúmore‚Äù . . . button

Linda D (Apple)
2022-06-10 00:29:39

*Thread Reply:* We're not fans of those either in the tab bar. They're very non-descriptive of the content that's inside and end up being a giant junk drawer in most IRL cases. Similar to the dreaded hamburger menu! Better to be purposeful about what the menu contains for navigation purposes and give it a specific name and icon.

Linda D (Apple)
2022-06-10 00:20:39

üßµ You may be familiar with hierarchal navigation as it‚Äôs so important when conveying progressive disclosure in an app.

‚ûï Andrew, Mike S (Apple), Eduardo, Lexline
Austin
2022-06-10 00:23:55

*Thread Reply:* Constant mixing of pushes within modals gives me the heebie-jeebies.

Linda D (Apple)
2022-06-10 00:24:22

üßµ Modality! We get a lot of questions about when to use modals and we cover a few considerations and examples in this section of the talk.

Andrew
2022-06-10 00:28:29

*Thread Reply:* Good section. Clear.

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-10 00:34:04

@Kyle asked > The wonderful crusade against home tabs reminds me of the one you did for hamburger menus many years back. Are there other common app conventions that you see that you disagree with?

üçî Lior, Linda D (Apple), Lexline, Serenity C (Apple), Mike S (Apple)
üçø Jordan, Leonard, Austin, Vidit
Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-10 00:34:46

*Thread Reply:* Thanks for remembering that session. It was YEARS ago.

Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-10 00:35:31

*Thread Reply:* We have a few, mostly they center on design conventions that come over from other platforms that could be adapted to match Apple platform conventions

Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-10 00:36:01

*Thread Reply:* For example, drawing a back button as an arrow (with a tail) instead of a chevron ( < )

Linda D (Apple)
2022-06-10 00:36:14

*Thread Reply:* ^ that's an android thing

ü§ñ Eduardo, Remi, Luca
Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-10 00:36:49

*Thread Reply:* Tab bars that have a button in the center that performs an action rather than navigating to a location in the app

üíØ Eduardo, Vidit, Yunson
Austin
2022-06-10 00:36:54

*Thread Reply:* One that comes to mind that might've been mentioned in that session is avoiding the standard Apple platform icon for share sheet button.

2022-06-10 00:37:00

Mike S (Apple)
