Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-10 00:37:34

@Martin asked > In reference to not creating a "home" tab, what are your thoughts on having "cards" that are overviews of content from a different tab? Would you consider that a duplicate?

Sarah M (Apple)
2022-06-10 00:40:39

*Thread Reply:* Hey @Martin, great question. This is highly dependent of the context and content of the app. Be cautious of cards that display unrelated or disparate types of information and make an interface feel like a dashboard. Dashboards are similar to Home tabs, as the information is not directly related and often overloaded. This makes it difficult to glance and takes longer to understand the relationships and how to take action

:gratitude_thank_you: Martin, Yunson
Jessiah
2022-06-10 00:43:31

*Thread Reply:* So, if you use cards or have a dashboard like view, try to keep the content relevant to the current tab?

üí™:skin_tone_2: Sarah M (Apple)
Adam H (Apple)
2022-06-10 00:44:00

*Thread Reply:* We‚Äôve seen some apps that have a wide array of Widgets that can be configured like a dashboard. It can be very powerful, especially on iPad. But these widgets would take you to the corresponding tab in the app.

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-10 00:39:50

@Eduardo asked > when do you recommend hiding the navigation bar when pushing a view? > Ex: Apple News: When you open an article, the app pushes the article view and hides the main navigation.

‚ûï Lexline, Andrew
Austin
2022-06-10 00:40:41

*Thread Reply:* Curious about if there are situations when the tab bar should be hidden also.

üíØ Eduardo, Lexline
Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-10 00:41:34

*Thread Reply:* It‚Äôs true that News doesn‚Äôt follow the typical convention we recommend for tabbed apps. I can‚Äôt really speak for the News team, but I believe the thinking was that people don‚Äôt generally switch between tabs frequently or want to persist state in each tab since the content changes all the time

üëç Eduardo, Yunson
Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-10 00:42:11

*Thread Reply:* People drill into articles, read, and then often leave.

Majo C (Apple)
2022-06-10 00:42:12

*Thread Reply:* You could consider temporarily hide the Navigation Bar for immersive experiences, just be sure to allow the reverse interaction and show it when swiping down or tapping the screen.

üëç Eduardo, Yunson
Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-10 00:43:38

*Thread Reply:* In that usage pattern, persisting the tab bar to allow for fast lateral navigation, or keeping it visible to help people stay oriented, is less of an imperative.

üëç Eduardo, Yunson
Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-10 00:43:48

*Thread Reply:* This is pretty atypical for tabbed apps though

üëç Eduardo, Yunson
Eduardo
2022-06-10 00:47:27

*Thread Reply:* got it! Yes I was thinking it can be also be possible to use a modal instead of a push with hidden nav bar

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-10 00:42:31

@Lior asked > I saw in Sarah M's session that there were Places cells with a ... button on their top right side. > On what cases should we use such a button?

‚ûï Andrew
Sarah M (Apple)
2022-06-10 00:43:26

*Thread Reply:* I believe you‚Äôre referring to the ellipses SF Symbol in the navigation bar?

Sarah M (Apple)
2022-06-10 00:44:04

*Thread Reply:* We would use this button for secondary actions that are related to the view, but perhaps not the primary actions someone would take

üëç Lior
Linda D (Apple)
2022-06-10 00:45:28

*Thread Reply:* "..." More menus are typically used to host a set of additional actions vs. navigation. You'll often see designs conflate the two.

üëç Lior
Jessiah
2022-06-10 00:48:47

*Thread Reply:* If an app must use more than 5 tabs, is an ellipsis the appropriate icon for the ‚ÄúMore‚Äù tab?

Christian
2022-06-10 12:12:48

*Thread Reply:* @Jessiah I believe that @Linda D (Apple) answered this here:

https://wwdc22.slack.com/archives/C03H77GM1NW/p1654813779763509?thread_ts=1654812948.356689&cid=C03H77GM1NW

} Linda D (Apple) (https://wwdc22.slack.com/team/U03DMQBFPH8)
<p>We're not fans of those either in the tab bar. They're very non-descriptive of the content that's inside and end up being a giant junk drawer in most IRL cases. Similar to the dreaded hamburger menu! Better to be purposeful about what the menu contains for navigation purposes and give it a specific name and icon.</p>
Original URL: https://wwdc22.slack.com/archives/C03H77GM1NW/p1654813779763509?thread_ts=1654812948.356689&amp;cid=C03H77GM1NW
From a thread in <b>#design-lounge</b>
üëç Jessiah
Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-10 00:44:06

@Benjamin asked > Are there resources we can share with more web-minded colleagues. It can be difficult to explain that apps and websites should not have the same navigation design.

Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-10 00:45:12

*Thread Reply:* Absolutely! developer.apple.com/design

Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-10 00:45:23

*Thread Reply:* Also this video üôÇ

Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-10 00:46:21

*Thread Reply:* I‚Äôm not sure we really speak explicitly to web designers per se, but this should be a helpful primer on Apple platform design patterns

Linda D (Apple)
2022-06-10 00:46:59

*Thread Reply:* Also more specifically all the content inside "Navigation and search" in the HIG https://developer.apple.com/design/human-interface-guidelines/components/navigation-and-search/navigation-bars

developer.apple.com
Navigation bars - Navigation And-search - Components - Human Interface Guidelines - Design - Apple Developer
A navigation bar appears at the top of an app screen, enabling navigation through a hierarchy of content.
Original URL: https://developer.apple.com/design/human-interface-guidelines/components/navigation-and-search/navigation-bars
Linda D (Apple)
2022-06-10 00:47:19

*Thread Reply:* As well as modality: https://developer.apple.com/design/human-interface-guidelines/patterns/modality

developer.apple.com
Modality - Patterns - Human Interface Guidelines - Design - Apple Developer
Modality is a design technique that presents content in a separate, focused mode that prevents interaction with the parent view and requires an explicit action to dismiss.
Original URL: https://developer.apple.com/design/human-interface-guidelines/patterns/modality
Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-10 00:47:18

@Sean asked > I saw in the session that there are list section headers that are bold and bigger than normal section headers. In which cases should we use these? Thanks

Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-10 00:48:33

*Thread Reply:* They‚Äôre a relative recent change to iOS (last year I think). It‚Äôs a matter of taste and judgement I think. But they‚Äôre particularly effective when the list is text only. It helps created needed differentiation (or grouping) between content items and category labels

Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-10 00:49:23

*Thread Reply:* If the list items are visually distinctive, larger section headers might not be needed. But, personally, I think they‚Äôre an improvement in all situations.

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-10 00:47:53

@Vidit asked > "Home" is such a lazy name for the app's first tab! But the argument that's often given in its favour is that people understand it because that's how the first page is often referred to in web and app design and changing it would mean forcing people to change their already established habits. > > Would Spotify / Twitter doing away with the home tab be a risky UI move that could lose them followers or a much needed navigation cleanse?

Majo C (Apple)
2022-06-10 00:50:56

*Thread Reply:* We can‚Äôt speak about what other companies should do, but I don‚Äôt consider risky moving to a more intuitive labeling convention, this way you ensure predictability and intention.

Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-10 00:51:47

*Thread Reply:* Specificity is always a good thing. If there‚Äôs a more descriptive word to use, it should be used.

üíØ Vidit, Linda D (Apple), Kyle, Yunson
Kyle
2022-06-10 00:52:26

*Thread Reply:* I was just thinking that. Maybe instead of ‚ÄúHome‚Äù it should just be ‚ÄúTimeline‚Äù for Twitter

üíØ Vidit, Lexline
Linda D (Apple)
2022-06-10 00:52:33

*Thread Reply:* And even web is starting to move away from the "home" concept. I have a feeling it will end up in the same category as having a floppy disk represent "save"

ü§û Majo C (Apple), Vidit, Lexline, Yunson
üòÄ Vidit
Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-10 00:48:13

@Sean asked > In the demo app shown, the Navigation Bar was hidden but the toolbar items was still showing. Is this new in iOS 16?! üòä

Sarah M (Apple)
2022-06-10 00:52:16

*Thread Reply:* Hmm. Can you elaborate what example you‚Äôre referring to?

Sarah M (Apple)
2022-06-10 00:52:47

*Thread Reply:* None of these examples share UI that isn‚Äôt yet released üòä

Benjamin
2022-06-10 00:55:00

*Thread Reply:* Navigation bar appearances? https://developer.apple.com/documentation/uikit/uinavigationbar/3198027-scrolledgeappearance

Sean
2022-06-10 00:55:47

*Thread Reply:* Yeah of course! If you notice how the image goes behind an invisible NavigationBar but the toolbar is still visible

Image from iOS
Image from iOS
Sarah M (Apple)
2022-06-10 00:56:47

*Thread Reply:* That‚Äôs a standard navigation bar with the background blur removed

Majo C (Apple)
2022-06-10 01:04:16

*Thread Reply:* The image goes behind the navigation bar and it‚Äôs optional to remove its background, but for TAB BARS it‚Äôs not recommended.

üíØ Benjamin, Sean
Sarah M (Apple)
2022-06-10 01:08:54

*Thread Reply:* Yes, the background translucency should not be changed or removed on the tab bar. On a navigation bar, it can be an aesthetic choice if it doesn‚Äôt hinder the user experience

üí• Eduardo, Majo C (Apple)

<p>@Kyle asked &gt; The wonderful crusade against home tabs reminds me of the one you did for hamburger menus many years back. Are there other common app conventions that you see that you disagree with?</p>

Thread in <b>#design-lounge</b>
Oliver
2022-06-10 00:50:26

*Thread Reply:* ‚ÄúKebab menu‚Äù? Is that a thing? now I‚Äôm hungry‚Ä¶

üòÇ Sarah M (Apple), Vidit, Lexline, Mike S (Apple)
ü§§ Anqi
Sarah M (Apple)
2022-06-10 00:50:37

*Thread Reply:* Most of these components are problematic for other reasons. For example, FABS tend to cover elements of an interface which can be difficult to read or interact with the content behind the action. They also tend to be duplicated across tabs and the redundancy, shows that the action lacks context

üëç Vidit, Linda D (Apple)
üíØ Linda D (Apple), Serenity C (Apple)
Linda D (Apple)
2022-06-10 00:50:47

*Thread Reply:* And yes to all of the above, a lot of those paradigms you'll see on Android and it instantly makes people feel as if the design wasn't intended for an Apple platform.

üëç Lior, Kyle, Vidit
Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-10 00:54:45

*Thread Reply:* Yes to above! I should add that FABs aren‚Äôt verboten on iOS but the action should be VERY important and VERY frequently used. Otherwise they get in the way. Things and Notes are two good examples of where a FAB makes sense. Problem is a lot of other apps use FABs for an action that isn‚Äôt all that common.

Oliver
2022-06-10 00:55:51

*Thread Reply:* After years of freelancing and working in startups, the most annoying thing was UI/UX concepts fighting against the (native) platform language - for the sake of brand experience, for ‚Äústreamlining and build it faster‚Äù (the opposite was true) or lack of knowledge (or empowerment) of the designers. It is really hard to find good mobile1st designers‚Ä¶. still after over 10yrs

Mike S (Apple)
2022-06-10 00:57:11

*Thread Reply:* We feel your pain.

Oliver
2022-06-10 00:58:31

*Thread Reply:* btw: I consider SwiftUI more a design than a code challenge‚Ä¶ (for the same reasons)

Austin
2022-06-10 00:58:46

*Thread Reply:* Agree Oliver. I'm not a designer but I've certainly tried to advocate for native look and feel when working with designers on iOS apps, @Mike S (Apple)'s session Essential Design Principles from WWDC 2017 helped clarify my thinking around this.

üëç Oliver, Orlando Gabriel, Junfeng
Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-10 00:54:06

@Lexline asked > Wondering where "featured" tabs would fall‚Äîare they just home tabs with a different name or could they actually be considered useful?

Sarah M (Apple)
2022-06-10 00:55:30

*Thread Reply:* Hi @Lexline, could you share what a feature tab would consist of?

Lexline
2022-06-10 00:56:12

*Thread Reply:* I guess maybe recommended articles for example?

Linda D (Apple)
2022-06-10 00:58:48

*Thread Reply:* Hard to say a blanket "yes or no" because it depends on the content inside the tab. We do "For You" tabs where the content inside changes dynamically based on what we think is relevant to the user. That could be considered a "featured" section but its use case is specific enough from navigation that it can be its own page

Linda D (Apple)
2022-06-10 00:59:28

*Thread Reply:* Where it gets iffy is when you're just repeating the same content as in your navigation put on a page. That causes confusion with whether people should use the tab bar or Featured page to access information

üëç Lexline
Majo C (Apple)
2022-06-10 01:00:04

*Thread Reply:* Recommended & feature articles could be highlighted under the Articles tab, instead of having a dedicated tab. I‚Äôd say, as @Linda D (Apple), that it would be case by case and depending of the level of personalization the app offers.

üëç Lexline
Lexline
2022-06-10 01:01:02

*Thread Reply:* Ah okay, that makes sense! Thank you!

üëè Majo C (Apple)

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-10 00:58:25

@Philip asked > I saw a tweet showing batch editing in the iOS 16 Photos app and apparently it uses a progress indicator at the bottom that reminds me of an Android-style snackbar/toast. Do you have any guidance on this UI element? https://twitter.com/apollozac/status/1534903049373761537

üëÄ Austin, Leonard
Sarah M (Apple)
2022-06-10 00:59:02

*Thread Reply:* We have progress indicators on iOS currently https://developer.apple.com/design/human-interface-guidelines/components/status/progress-indicators

developer.apple.com
Progress indicators - Status - Components - Human Interface Guidelines - Design - Apple Developer
Progress indicators let people know that your app isn‚Äôt stalled while it loads content or performs lengthy operations.
Original URL: https://developer.apple.com/design/human-interface-guidelines/components/status/progress-indicators
Linda D (Apple)
2022-06-10 01:00:15

*Thread Reply:* We don't currently have published design guidance on that particular style of progress indicator (when it becomes more common the platform we'll consider).

Philip
2022-06-10 01:01:39

*Thread Reply:* Gotcha! Thanks for your answers, @Sarah M (Apple) and @Linda D (Apple). I really enjoy reading through the conversations going on here.

üíØ Benjamin, Sean, Arthur
Linda D (Apple)
2022-06-10 01:02:51

*Thread Reply:* Although from prior experience I can say that what that toasts are tricky to work with. The one you're seeing in iOS 16 is nice because it's using a deliberate "x" close button so people can dismiss the UI and it knows the process takes long enough that the toast won't magically disappear in 1 sec making it impossible to read or interact with

üëç Kyle, Yunson
Philip
2022-06-10 01:03:33

*Thread Reply:* So it's not disappearing automatically after the batch edit has completed? I need to try it myself, I guess‚Ä¶

Linda D (Apple)
2022-06-10 01:04:59

*Thread Reply:* It is disappearing automatically after the batch edit completes, but the reason it appears in the first place is that batch edits take time so it's appropriate for this context

üëç Philip, Andrew, Yunson
Linda D (Apple)
2022-06-10 01:01:53

Wow time just FLEW by! Because I missed the memo it's at the hour, I'll give 2 more minutes to get any final questions in there.

üïî Lior, Lexline, Remi, Serenity C (Apple), Sean
Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-10 01:02:18

@Lior asked > In the "Explore navigation design for iOS" session there is an example of a "Profile" Tab which I've seen several apps using, but others like f.e. the Appstore uses Profile as button in the top-right side. > Does that depend on the importance of such a Profile screen ? > in other words, What makes something to be a "tab-worthy" ?

‚ûï Benjamin
Sarah M (Apple)
2022-06-10 01:03:44

*Thread Reply:* Great question, @Lior. This is a judgement call based off of the importance of the profile. In many cases, the profile is not that important to the apps main functionality and it isn‚Äôt needed as a tab bar item.

üíØ Lior
üëç Lior
Sarah M (Apple)
2022-06-10 01:04:36

*Thread Reply:* When considering what should be a tab, think of your apps menu of options. When tabs are designed well, they tell a story at a glance about what your app can do and how people can use it. Profile tends to be less important in the scheme of things.

üëç Kyle, Lior
Sarah M (Apple)
2022-06-10 01:05:34

*Thread Reply:* And just because you have tabs to use, doesn‚Äôt mean you have to use them all. Sometimes an app will feel more approachable if the tabbed navigation is simplified

Adam H (Apple)
2022-06-10 01:06:06

*Thread Reply:* Agree with @Sarah M (Apple). Also, if the user needs to access the Profile content regularly and you don‚Äôt want to place a profile button in the nav bar of every tab, a profile tab may be a better option.

üíØ Lior, Linda D (Apple), Yunson
Jordan
2022-06-10 01:46:57

*Thread Reply:* Side note I wish the Updates tab were restored in App Store, I check for app updates multiple times a day and read the release notes. Def inefficient to open the profile screen. (Yes I might have a problem üòÜ)

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-10 01:04:50

@Oliver asked > Another "heated" topic: where to put the X/close/cancel button - top left or top right? Are there really no guidelines about it? Confuses the hell out me (as a user and developer)

‚ù§Ô∏è Benjamin, Vidit, Lexline, Yunson, Tiago, Zeke
‚ûï Jordan, Tiago
Majo C (Apple)
2022-06-10 01:09:35

*Thread Reply:* @Oliver I totally understand how this could be confusing. You‚Äôre right, top right accessories are used for the main actions. But in the case of Modals there might be other resources more suitable - like buttons - to convey important actions. So Close takes the top right place. I‚Äôd say that prioritization of the actions on screen are key here, once you have a clear understanding - you could decide what‚Äôs the best pattern to follow.

Linda D (Apple)
2022-06-10 19:20:32

*Thread Reply:* @Oliver a bit late but your question is answered here: https://wwdc22.slack.com/archives/C03H77GM1NW/p1654807862947179

<p>@Gary asked &gt; For full screen modals with no interaction, is Apple's preferred dismiss control an X in a circle in the top right corner (as is referenced in the Explore Navigation Design for iOS talk) as opposed to a grab style control at the top middle (indicating to pull down to close)?</p>
Original URL: https://wwdc22.slack.com/archives/C03H77GM1NW/p1654807862947179

Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-10 01:16:46

@Kyle asked > It struck me that tab bars and navigation bars are, at least in principle, identical to the original iPhone interaction paradigm. I‚Äôm wondering what the biggest difference you‚Äôve seen in navigation is, since that first iPhone?

‚ù§Ô∏è Jordan, Brandon, Yunson, Tiago
Sarah M (Apple)
2022-06-10 01:20:22

*Thread Reply:* I love this question. I wish I had the time to answer more thoroughly. Here are some thoughts about tab bars and navigation bars: these components and interaction patterns clearly resonated with people. Maybe that was luck, maybe it‚Äôs a pattern that reflected our natural understanding of how things are organized and arranged already in the world around us. But they have evolved and modernized while staying true to what ‚Äòjust worked‚Äô originally. As people‚Äôs comfort with apps grow, new patterns emerge to support new complexity such as sidebar being a solution specific to a new device and form factor

üíØ Kyle, Serenity C (Apple), Zhang, Linda D (Apple), Yunson, Alexander, Andreas, Nordin
Design - Ask a Question
2022-06-10 17:49:23

@Willey asked > Thank you for such an amazing WWDC! I definitely learned a lot this week. One last question from me: what are some books/resources that you would recommend every designer to read for design guidance, creative inspiration, best practices, etc (besides Apple's HIG, of course)?

Linda D (Apple)
2022-06-10 18:00:59

*Thread Reply:* For me: ‚Ä¢ Free Play: Improvisation in Life and Art ‚Äì Not specific to UX but this has really helped me unblock myself creatively ‚Ä¢ Interaction of Color by Josef Albers ‚Äì Great color theory resource ‚Ä¢ ElementsofTypographicStyle?fromsearch=true&fromsrp=true&qid=Q1DklR77Li&rank=1|The Elements of Typographic Style >‚Äì Great typography resource ‚Ä¢ In Praise of Shadows ‚Äì Lovely essay on aesthetic

‚ù§Ô∏è Lexline, Willey, Jose Felipe, Sam

Linda D (Apple)
2022-06-10 19:32:39

In addition to your feedback in the thread above about how we can help you better design Our WWDC22 Developer Survey is now live!

This is for WWDC22 in general and what we could make better for you. Your feedback has major impact on the programs and events we host. üôèüíñ

essentials.applesurveys.com
Apple
Thanks for joining us this year. WWDC is designed for you and your feedback is important to us. Providing responses to this survey is voluntary. It should take 5 minutes or less of your time. Do not include any information that may identify you in the text boxes. Your responses will not be tied to you and will be aggregated with other responses.
Original URL: https://essentials.applesurveys.com/jfe/form/SV_2cw6N3JbrxFcoiq
